The primary reason saw to help me lose weight. It pairs nicely with the apps, phone and smart scale to help me track and encourage my progress. I was 220 pounds in September. As of this morning I am down to 184.3
I also programmed one of the buttons with Alexa. That has given me great peace of mind. I never walk into a dark house again. Before entering the house, I simply press the Alexa button and turn on the desired lighting. It also comes in handy while enjoying the cinematic universe. My echo can't always hear me over the movies. Now, with a push of a bottom and a whisperer command, I can adjust the lighting and even pause my program.
I also have a 94 year old mother. This watch allows me to avoid those pesty scam calls while at work yet keep in touch should any issues arise with mom.
My next test will be to try and add the app for my security cam to keep an eye on the house while I'm away.
I've ready many reviews on poor battery life, however as this watch does not teach sleep, I simply put it on the charger every night. I have never come close to draining the battery day to day.
The price while steep for a watch was worth every dollar. I truly enjoy waking up and putting on my watch every morning and highly recommend this watch for anyone who would like a touch of class.
Lone Wolf. RCK IL

To be perfectly clear: this is an EXCELLENT watch (after all Fossil makes other great watches), but it runs on Wear OS, which is far from perfect. The hardware is pretty much unbeatable for the price. Heart rate monitoring is great, the speaker and mic is clear enough to make phone calls on, and the battery life is enough to last a full day of normal use (with pretty much all features enabled).
Now, onto the bad part. Wear OS (at the time of writing), to put it simply, sucks. A lot. Sometimes, it will disconnect your watch from Bluetooth for no reason, won't connect automatically, and has quite a few weird bugs. Now I'm assuming Google will continue to improve it, but right now, it's not very good. It works (with some inconveniences) but I think the hardware makes up for most of it.
In short, Fossil has made a great watch, really stylish, durable (I use a SuperShieldz screen protector and have banged it up quite a bit with no visible damage to the watch whatsoever), and half the price of its competitors. So I do recommend it, but just be aware that there are some inconveniences with Wear OS (but I don't think it's fair to fault Fossil for them).

The Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle is a solid watch, after setting up I haven't had any major issues with it. Do get a screen protector, I have a desk job and still managed to scratch it. And the included band I got isn't the most comfortable BUT I still haven't bought a band to replace it so that tells you it's not a major issue.

Battery life for the Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle is "decent", at this point I have the Heart Rate Monitor checking every minute, WIFI on, Always On screen on and GPS on as well as sleep with the watch on. I get through a 7AM-5PM work day with about 25% left, charge for less than an hour total before bedtime and still wake up with about 60-50% left in the morning before another short charge prior to leaving for the day.

Overall I have no buyers remorse getting this watch, which is what you should take away. (Side note my wife has an Apple Watch and she likes the features my Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle has over hers; she just won't get off the Apple train.)

I really liked the watch and the interface when it worked. The watch does not turn on. I tried charging overnight, different outlets, and power blocks. I only had the watch for 9 days. I charged it nightly with the charger provided. I took it off for showers as well.

Well, to start with I just moved over from the iOS ecosystem to Android world, and love my new, shiny Samsung Galaxy Note 10. So, this Fossil Gen 5 release date was Godsend to coincide with my decision to switch to Android and Note 10 release as my old Apple Watch won't work with my new Android phone.

Absolutely floored by the slim design of Fossil Watch, how easily it connected with my Note 10. Aesthetics wise I like it more than my Apple Watch; even got praises on how well it looks.

And the fascination just stopped there. I wish the screen could be more brighter. I have set the brightness at 5 (maximum) and I still thinks it's not bright enough. And the battery life. Within just 6 hours of use, my watch came down from 100% to 24%! Well, the watch boasts of "Extended" and "Time Only" modes in addition to the "Daily" mode (with all the smart features enabled). I looked at the "Extended" mode setting to find out that all the features are set to OFF in the watch except you can hit the crown to wake up your watch, notifications and vibrations are On, and the Bluetooth is available from 6 AM - 10 PM only. All the cool options, such as Speaker, WiFi, Touch-to-wake, Tilt-to-Wake, NFC, OK Google detect options are disabled.

Come on; I bought a smart watch for a reason. Otherwise, $295 would have fetched me a very stunning and performant non-smart watch.

Let's not even imagine what the third, "Time Only", option would turn my watch into. Perhaps, every time I needed to see time in my watch, I had to call Fossil customer care and then they would have either enabled the display for 10 seconds or just told me over the phone what I wanted to know from my watch!

Perhaps, I am being harsh but I can't help it when I am coming from a perfectly fine smartwatch (Apple Watch) that won't work with Android phones, and you're just left to this.

Fossil, I urge you to work on the battery drainage and brightness things as the top-priority things to fix in this watch. Otherwise, you will just end up with customers like me who are not all happy with this purchase. I won't recommend this watch, at least not until Fossil fixed the battery issue at the minimum!

I used to have various Wear OS watches since the first release, and I see this Fossil Gen 5 as an absolute winner. Its design and quality far exceed all alternatives, both past and current. Initially, I hesitated to buy it for $300+ (its list price on the Fossil site) as I used Fossil Gen 3 Explorist and was mostly satisfied with it, but the Black Friday deal convinced me to give a try. And I never ever looked back and have hidden the Explorist immediately.

The watch is fast, charges very quickly (more on this below) and has all technologies that it has to (I see zero use in cellular connectivity in the watch, so its lack in Gen 5 doesn't hurt me). I have yet to test NFC as Google Pay doesn't work on watches in most of Europe (brain-dead idea to let it run on the phone and not on the watch), but this is not the watch's fault and I just need to find an alternative payment mechanism to test NFC properly.

On the bad side is a low time on battery. I do use heart monitoring every 15 minutes during the day and more frequently at night, and this causes the battery to stay for less than 24 hours. But you know what? Having a *fast* charger and a metal band solves this problem completely - I can easily take the watch off and put it back on, and charging it in twice a day for ~30 minutes in total is much less than charging my Gen 3 Explorist for over 2 hours once a day (and less than any other watch on the market, as I understand it).

So, I highly recommend this watch and wish that the vendor continues its great job in the future.

Great wear is watch. Had the Moto 360 and then the Asus Zenwatch 2 before this fossil and can easily say this is a clear and substantial improvement in all aspects and what a wear device should be.

Battery life is great, it easily last all day with normal (this means heartband fitness tracking, always on display, GPS ans wifi on) use with plenty to spare. It won't go two full days with this use but maybe a day and a half. There are modes to increase battery life if you need a longer stretch, and they're easy to select.

Display is crisp and allows for small font to really add utility. Some flickering occurs with certain 3rd party faces in ambient mode; haven't had a chance to dive deeper on the actual cause. But it's rare and a different watchface won't have that issue.

Performance is great, apps open quickly, no delay while navigating the OS.

The only con I have is the bezel on the display leaves a blank, black border between the edge of the screen and the edge of the body of the watch. This is more pronounced with white display. The display is large enough, however, so this is more of an easthetic issue than a functional one

Overall, great watch. Finally everything works as it should and there is no lag while using the watch.

I really enjoyed this watch when I was working. I wore this watch everyday for a year and out of nowhere it just stopped working. It won't charge or turn on. Very frustrating, and it's really hard for you to get it serviced through fossil. I won't be getting this watch again.

I've had this watch for less than a year when it stopped turning on. I tried everything I could find on the internet regarding this issue, which does not seem to be uncommon, and nothing worked. I contacted Fossil and sent the watch in to be repaired. They sent the watch back with a form letter stating the part needed to repair the watch was unavailable. That's it, no further explanation was made. I called the customer care number and was told they are no longer able to repair the watch as the parts (module in my case) was no longer available. I asked why they wouldn't at least replace my watch and they said they are no longer producing Gen 5 watches. After some consternation, the rep called me back and offered to give me store credit for my original purchase price toward the purchase of a current model of fossil watch, which have awful reviews and are not visually appealing to me. But I was told its either that or nothing! Awful customer service, the watch is still under warranty but they will not honor it beyond store credit for whatever they are producing at the time of redemption.
The condition of the battery (less than 3 hours)

I really wanted to love this watch, but it's just not quite there. I went from apple, to a pixel phone last year. I had the apple watch and it just worked so so well.... The watch was a seemless extension of your phone, and everything about it seemed natural. Pixel doesn't have a watch (yet?) But after a lot of review, this seemed like the best watch for me. I wanted good battery life, ability for two way communication (speaker and mic) run wearos well, at a decent price. While all of that is somewhat true, the execution just stuggles. Most of the time the watch runs well. I get notifications, I have used ok Google and I have answered phone calls. But it has been very noticable for the times any of those haven't worked.

The part that gets me the most is it will turn off Bluetooth without notice, for no reason. It's not exactly easy to turn it back on either. That of course Is a huge deal, no need to explain more there. I did fix it with a Bluetooth schedule feature, but I couldn't just leave it on, or else it would turn off.

Another annoying thing is the alarm. This issue is just poor software design (not sure if it's the os or fossil) but basically the watch alarm can function in two ways. One is solely managed on the watch, the other is an extended alarm from your phone. The phone alarm integration could be nice, but it's very very much not. When you turn an alarm on you phone, it will alarm on your phone and watch at the same time, and there is no turning this off. You can turn it down on the watch, but you can diffinitely still hear it. I would just do an alarm on my watch which is what the plan was, but the buttons do not snooze or have any function with the alarm. I wear glasses so the whole thing is just a pain, and I don't think there's any reason this should be an issue.

Another part is the call management. Right out of the box it did not work well. There was a software update needed and surprisingly enough that fixed a call quality issue. But it does not consistently answer on the watch when you press answer on the watch, and vice versa. At work I run Vonage. And I have my extension set up on my cellphone. However there is no way to direct a Vonage phone call to directly go to my phone rather than the watch. There's no way to manage this is Vonage, or in wearOS. I have unfortunaely had to disable the call feature completely because I almost never want to answer a work call on my watch

Again I really, really wanted to love it, but most of the reasons I got this watch are unreliable. I still use it, but unfortunately not to it's listed full potential

I haven't owned the watch for long but I want to give some initial impressions with more to follow after extended use.

The watch looks nice and has a decent weight out of the package, coming from a Citizen Ecodrive this thing does feel a whole lot lighter. I prefer my watches to feel like they are there, and this watch performs that decently.

The screen is responsive and I have had no issues with battery life as I don't use the watch as my only way of interacting with my phone, just an alternative in certain situations.

My biggest gripe is how cheap the watch materials feel. I understand at this price point I could get a very nice mechanical watch that feels like it was worth the price I paid. This watch, especially this metal band, feels like one wrong move and it is going to disintegrate. I also resized the band and the pins holding each link together felt very brittle. so I worry that if I use this band in any physical activity it will not last.

Overall, inital impressions, I would rate this a 7/10. Buy it if it is on sale, and avoid it if it is not.

When this watch works, its great.  I LOVE several features, mainly the "easy voice recorder" Its the only reason I haven't moved away from it.
However, the small defects render this totally unusable.

1) the power button gets jammed often.  When this happens the watch shuts down and usually will not power back up until you hook it to power.  This can happen quite easily: doing a push up, cutting onions.  Anything where your wrist is bent basically.  This will kick it into a cycle of reboots, or it just wont turn on (sometimes it wont even respond to the hard reset, pressing 2 buttons for 10 seconds).  You have to hook it to power.  I bought 3 more cables for my car, backpack etc just for this, but it shouldn't need it.

- a simple fix would be to have the watch able to flip orientation, but i don't think there is a way to do this.

2) the screen is not very responsive to touch.  I often have to press it 4 times to send a message after typing. I've tried variations of this, long presses, short taps, tapping dead center or not....still sucks

3) voice to text works....sometimes.  It loads and loads, then doesn't work

4) the watchband is trash.  I broke 2 in the first month before ordering a metal one, which is really uncomfortable, but it doesn't fall off my wrist while 20ft in the air (true story)

5) bluetooth turns off a lot.  My research says this may be because I keep it in "extended battery mode".  But it wont get through a full work day if I don't.

Pros: the easy voice recorder is the single greatest feature of any product ever.  I push 1 button and talk into my wrist to save ideas.  My memory sucks, but this solves it....(but AGAIN...when it works).  It saves even when not tethered to phone.  The app is simple, i can dump the files to my computer to more easily step through them.
you can even record incriminating conversations or funny things your kids say, all very secretly.

The 1 push timer button is also great.

Those feature have kept me on this for a year, but every 3 days I want to throw it at the wall.  It seems to be getting worse also.  More disconnections, less battery, turns off after a cool breeze kicks up.

Fix these things and you have an advocate for life.....

I used to have the Huawei watch. It's a couple of years old now and battery life was getting poor so I thought the Gen 5 would be a good watch to move to. I love this watch. It brought back the feeling I first had with my old Huawei. It does everything my old watch did only faster. And although I haven't used it for it's fitness tracking, I have used the ability to answer a call using just the watch. While some people have complained about that feature, I think it works great. People can't tell I'm using my watch and their voice is clear and loud enough. And initiating a call is just as easy as answering one.
Notifications work flawlessly and am able to reply to text easily. The battery is great in that it's been 16 hours since it was charged and it's at 55%. That included having two conversations and having the brightness set to 3 out of five. I have found that the auto brightness is a little too dim for me so I don't use that option. Now, I am not monitoring my heart rate yet as that's not important to me right now, so I'm sure the battery will be a little lower with it on. It takes less than an hour to recharge and unlike my Huawei the charging contacts work every time. I got the metal band and it snaps easily without opening by itself.
My wife was so impressed with this watch that she also has the Gen 5, only the Rose Gold/Blush Julianna version. She wanted the Blush strap and as others have said it does tend to show, shall I say, a little darkening around the edges, but since other straps are available she's not worried.
I am completely satisfied with this purchase and am looking forward to using the other features it is capable of, feeling they too will operate as good as any other smart watch.

The Fossil Gen 5 (Carlyle in my case) is one of the most feature-heavy smartwatches that remains affordable for most looking at a watch. I was somewhat hesitant when I saw several reviews bashing the battery life, but as of this review, I've worn it daily for the last month with no problems.

I work a typical 9-5, and by the end of the day, my watch is usually sitting at around 75%. This is with the standard battery mode enabled, and with many features (fitness tracker/GPS/etc) enabled.
The Fossil gen 5 comes with Wear OS, and as someone who transitioned from Tizen previously, I couldn't be happier. I do wish Google would come through with some major updates, but for now, it functions as it should.

The screen is great if you're looking for a bright display with a great pixel density. While the bezel doesn't rotate, the spinning crown is comfortable for anything I have to work with. The Snapdragon Wear 3100 SoC makes the performance a  breeze despite being a little aged and performance seems to be on par with even the most loaded watches (such as the Skagen Falster 3)

The watch also has 8GB of onboard memory, so if you're a person who often has their watch away from their phone this should be a great perk for you. The fitness tracker seems to be very accurate as well, however, I'm not a fitness expert and have only ever used the built-in trackers from previous smartwatches.

Overall, the watch is a great value. I'd highly recommend it for anyone who's looking to purchase their first smartwatch or are transitioning from older hardware.

I bought this watch because it was coined as a Smartwatch flagship for the Wear OS. My previous watch was a Samsung Gear S3, and so the bar was already high.

This watch remains faithful to the Wear OS ecosystem, and by that I mean it uses the stock software provided by Google faithfully. This is a double edge sword. The Google Assistant on the watch will not send text messages to contacts - it encounters an error with the phone everytime. I got around this by going into the messages app on the watch and then replying to a message using the microphone. Another issue is that I cannot switch to calls on the watch when I initially took the call on the phone; it works if you answer a call on the watch, but not switching during a call. Another major issue is that the battery gets obliterated if you're playing music on your phone and the music controls display on the watch. Even if you don't touch the watch, the fact that it gets the music data in the controls drains the battery horribly... HORRIBLY.

Learning how to maximize the various battery modes has been imperative with this watch - you have to know when to switch to which mode if you hope to make it through the day without having to take it off and charge it.

I switched to this watch because it was supposed to be a flagship in representing the Wear OS. Let me tell you, if this is as good as Wear OS gets, then Wear OS sucks. If my Samsung Gear S3 wouldn't have become painfully slow from all of the software updates from Samsung, I would probably still use it today. But, Samsung messed that watch up by trying to keep it current with the watches in their showcase despite the hardware not being able to keep up. Also, I bought a new phone that's not a Samsung and don't want to bloat my phone with the Samsung stuff needed for that watch to work.

Note: the charging mechanism for this watch is very touchy. It will repeatedly beep like it's been just placed on the charger... REPEATEDLY. Rubbing off the contacts from any sweat residue makes little to no difference. Do not charge your watch at night because it just might prevent you from sleeping with this annoyance. Who engineered this?!

All in all, this watch is a "meh" for me, and even that is being generous. I've had better, and it was Samsung when they don't cripple the watch with software updates that the hardware can't keep up with. Yes, some of the issues are out of Fossil's control, but they still are accountable for quality assurance. The battery drain, the charging mechanism, and being aware of the power modes is what ruins the experience the most.

I have owned smart watches since before they were called smart watches.  Typical issues I tolerated with previous generations include very sluggish processors, Bluetooth loss of sync, very poor battery life with no way to even consider an "always on" display if I wanted to get more than 12 to 15 hours out of the watch, clunky "blah" appearance or too heavy, washed out screen outdoors, and no water proof ratings.  The Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle in a gunmetal grey metal band addresses and in every one of the above specifications, is noticeably better, allows you to take or make a call and talk on the watch, is more responsive with larger memory and storage and (with some tweaking of the settings over the first few days) now has been consistently providing me with a 7:00AM- 11:00PM day with 25-35% battery life remaining.  That is with most features turned on but with no use of the speakerphone for calls.  It works very well when swimming and I have always had it in the water during the summer and never missed a tick.
There are plenty of apps available and my having a weather radar on the screen background is so convenient - and the Hello Google feature allows me to dictate text messages with 95% accuracy regardless of whether I just say a phrase or dictate a couple of sentences.  At a sub $200 price, it is the best accessory I have to go with my phone.

Loved the watch, never dropped it or submerged in salt water or strapped it to a rocket and sent it to the tesla roadster, I mean sure it's scratched but I'm a mechanic and cement driveways aren't quite silicone soft so ??, Yea so I wore it every day, worked as well as any I suppose but today it ummm, well see it told me to uhhhh.... Get Bent, not sure why but something tells me scratches are a valid excuse to void the non-warranty... atleast that's what most companies do, cough cough motorola/samsung/lg cough, so yea I'm not going through the warranty trash for it to be blamed on me using superficial reasoning, don't y'all know a scratched screen can cause batteries to not take a charge or even...explode??, with that said your results may very, this one never lost its glass, or buttons, or charging strips(until 12/4/22), it didn't explode(yet), the screen and glass are in solid condition, scratching is normal, maybe grab a clear case and screen protector, but to be fair 8months with only scratching, that isn't to bad, I feel it could have made it 2 yrs, if it felt like it, I guess, the oled was sharp enough, battery life could improve like by 50%, js, but here's what really annoys me.  no more software updates, because of this I won't buy from fossil again, this is my first smart watch I've ever owned, won't wast my money again, sure it wasn't but $250+ doll hairs, but for only 8 months of life, idk. Again here are the positives, the oled is solid, glass is solid, sound could be louder but good enough, the battery could be better but does the job, I never dropped or placed in water, so why die with 54% battery???????

************UPDATE************
So 48hours later she poped on all willy-nilly like acting all normal like and s***..... you know just like it never happened... probably fits a warranty repair, but you know fossil doesn't  provide a useful warranty, almost like they don't stand behind their products or care about their customer's, don't believe me see attached picture.
************UPDATE2***********
Well didn't even make it 2 years, so the charging strips are falling off now and the battery heats up while in time only mode, which is the lowest power consumption mode the watch has, Every 30 to 45 days this watch requires a reset to factory settings, with this being my experience over 2 yrs I will not be purchasing another fossil product, my next watch will be a samsung galaxy watch 5 pro.

Update: After escalating this issue, Fossil did in fact provide a replacement. I've changed my overall rating to reflect that their customer service did the fair thing in the end since the watch malfunction wasn't my fault and I allowed them twice to repair it. It is a great watch when it worked and I would recommend it in that context.

My watch keeps rebooting requiring a reset which only stops the issue temporarily. I sent it in for warranty service twice and it still is not fixed. I contacted Fossil a third time requesting a replacement because I really like the watch when it works. THEIR reponse is it is now out of warranty and I AM responsible for any costs incurred for repair for this existing issue that never was fixed under warranty (so no replacement obviously). Disappointed to say the least. I'll post any update but for now, I'd stay away from Fossil smartwatch products.

I previously had a Garmin Fenix 3 HR but wasn't using most the functionality on it and wanted a more attractive everyday watch.  Based on reviews, I settled on the Fossil Carlyle Gen 5.

What a difference. Instead of being clunky and slow and quite ugly, it's fast and smooth and beautiful with a great feel and screen.

The OS is smooth and easy to use, but boy do you pay for it in battery life.  Out of the box this thing was burning through maybe 1% every few minutes, just by being on my wrist doing nothing.
 When I started interacting with it to explore it the battery was going down even faster, maybe 10% in 10 minutes.

I read of many similar complaints and there are Reddit threads discussing how to get reasonable battery life from it. In the end I used the custom battery mode option where I disabled pretty much everything apart from Bluetooth and always on screen and the things you can't turn off like heart rate; no location, wifi, tilt to wake , NFC, ok Google etc.  I didn't want most of those anyway.

Wow. What a difference. Now I make it home after a full day at work (maybe 12h) with 60+% battery remaining.  I charge twice a day, whilst I shower in the morning, and half an hour or so before bed. Bi use sleep as Android for sleep movement and heart rate tracking with the watch and that similarly uses ~40% battery overnight.

Mostly I use the watch for the time and controlling music; I have all but a few notifications turned off, so in truth other than heartrate monitoring it doesn't do much "smart", so from that perspective the battery life is dreadful, but it gets me through a day of regular usage which is acceptable.

If you think you're going to track hikes or navigate via gps from it, or spend hours playing around with it, don't buy.  You'll be disappointed. I'm keeping my Garmin for outdoor use and using this for daily wear.

Fossil, change your default battery mode; I nearly returned this it was SO BAD out of the box.  And for goodness sake make it a little thicker and put some more juice in it.
Purchased for my boyfriend and he loves it, it has a large display, he can receive all his notifications, it has a pretty good battery life, it’s water resistant and the app makes it easy to set up.

A few months ago I saw some family checking messages on a watched so I did some light research and chose this specific watch. I wear it daily and absolutely fell in love with it's functionality and easy of use.

Being google compatible made this watch for me since the rest of my house is google enabled. Being able to have a voice command on my wrist to set timers for work, play music, check messages and take calls is great. The little speaker on there isn't bad and the mic picks up commands well too. My favorite low key feature is when I'm playing music on my phone to my portable speaker I can leave both on the charger and literally adjust the volume with the dial on the watch and tap to change songs!

It also houses a small amount of apps from the Google play store that have a few time passing games as well. Also, if you have picture text messages on your phone they'll display on this watch as well.

Google fit enabled so the heart rate and exercise info syncs with the phone and scale in the restroom. I also like the theater mode to have it hush and dim while watching movies. Lastly to end my rambling, asking google to find my phone from this watch has saved me so much time since I tend to actually misplace my phone around the house.

Great impression and I don't see myself replacing it for a very long time at this rate.

I got this watch in January 2021 after my Galaxy S2 died, and it seemed ok. I specifically wanted Google Assistant, heart rate monitoring, and notifications from my phone--and it delivered on all of those. A few things seemed lacking, and I got the opportunity to try the Fitbit Versa 3--which revealed how bad this watch really is. Here are my findings as of August 2021:

Battery life. The Fossil Gen 5 originally lasted 1.5-2 days, in less than 4 months it started going into battery saving mode by 7pm. I charge it every night, so it's definitely not able to do sleep tracking during that time. I was accustomed to charging my Galaxy S2 every night, even though it would last 2-3 days on a charge, so that wasn't a big deal--until I got the Fitbit V3. The Fitbit's charge has only dropped ~10% per day (full day with sleep tracking all night) and charges 9% during a quick shower after my morning workout. There is absolutely no comparison.

Alarms. I spent hours trying to get my phone alarms to stop duplicating on the watch. My options were to disconnect from the watch every evening, endure duplicate alarms from my phone and watch every morning, or let it charge in the other room. I opted to let it charge in my office.

Voice Assistant. The voice assistant technically works, but I would find myself repeating the same commands 3-4 times slowly before it would take. I assumed this was the cost of having a mic inside a watch, but my Fitbit V3 has no difficulty hearing me the first time--every time.

Heart Rate Monitoring. It has a heart rate monitor, and it will check occasionally--or when explicitly told to. I assumed that's what the heart rate monitor was supposed to do, but the Fitbit V3 actually increases the sampling rate when I'm exercising and reads far more often--giving me much more confidence in the data.

Buttons. When I do pushups, the button on the Fossil does a long-press on my wrist and sometimes the button sticks--requiring me to pull it back out. It's only 7 months old!

Notifications. It did notifications just fine, but so does the Fitbit V3.

A few months ago, friend of mine wanted to get a smartwatch and asked me if I'd recommend my watch. At the time, I said, "It depends on what you want the watch for. This watch is optimized for the things I'm using it for, but I can't recommend it for general use." Now I can confidently say, no. I don't recommend it. Get a Fitbit Versa 3 or something that's even on the same playing field.

I love this watch so much!  It looks great, the love the features, its easy to use.  There is very little about it that I dislike.  however, There is a glitch that persisted on my other Fossil smartwatch as well that causes the watch to randomly shut off.  The only way to turn it back on is to put it on the charger for a few moments.  The battery is NOT dead either.  The watch usually has a high charge after it turns back on.  This is very frustrating and really takes away from a genuinly great product.  Please fix this issue, Fossil!

First the good parts. I like the look of this watch (I have the smoke color). I think it looks better in "real life" than in the photos.  It is a nice size (I am not a big person), and I like that I can easly put any 22mm band on it.  Also, the display is crisp and bright. It even squeeks by in bright sun.

On the other side, the battery and battery management are marginal. There are four battery profiles.  The default profile, named "daily" won't get me through a typical day without an afternoon top-up.  Two other profiles, "extended" and "time only", turn off the "always on display", which is unacceptable to me.  That leaves the "custom" display. I use it with the display & bluetooth on, location (gps and compass) on or off as I need them, and just about everything else off.  This gets me through a day with some power to spare. But I have to pay attention.  I'm also not convinced, based on watching the battery drain, that the software is telling me everything about what battery things are on or off.  I find it necessary to "re-assert" the custom profile every so often.

Overall I like this watch, but I think we have a ways to go before smart watches are more than a tech toy.

Update 12/1/2023:
----------------------
The watch finally died abruptly while wearing last night. It was 90% charge as I took it out of the charger a little while ago. Went cold dead. After the original review below, I managed the settings such that with most connectivities off it would last full day. So I was okay and I bought a couple of dozens of watch faces and used to change them often. Also bought additional charging stands chargers and bands. Down the drain. They are not super expensive. But they are all pile of garbage now at home all of a sudden.

Original Review:
-------------------
I have seen smart watches on other people for years and stuck to my old fashioned Seiko analog. Finally, I bought this one after looking around reviews and comparison. Apple watch wasn't an option for me. We have dozens of Android but no Apple devices.

Now, the watch does work per spec. That wasn't the reason for my lower than 5 ?? rating. I rated for what value I derive and satisfaction with the use.

1. The watch is bulkier than my old fashioned watch. Not very aesthetically pleasing. Although, this looked better/sober among various models. This is minor. I don't dislike it, at the same time not overly enthusiastic to wear it.

2. It took some time to understand the quirks of how this watch behaves for the first time. This is not a complaint. Being a techie, I pick up fairly quickly.

3. Google Pay on the watch requires screen lock for security. The logic is understandable, but ridiculous for a watch to be unlocked frequently. Google has to find a way to drive security from phone to watch differently. Don't know how. But there must be a user friendly option. This is just bizarre.

4. Watch screen. This is the problematic part. Apparently, the watch makers can only squeeze in so much battery power. Hence, there is a whole bunch of ways they try to save power so that it lasts for a day's use. And as a result, their automatic screen brightness is pathetic. You can barely see it.

5. Watch faces. The initial euphoria of being able to change faces wears out very quickly when you realize that there are very few useful faces delivered with the watch. The list of faces are plain ridiculous and cartoonish to my taste. May be good for others. I like clean faces with analog clock and digital info snippets. Found only one I could use. Then I started scavenging the app store. Because, they advertise that they got tens of thousands! Well, after I kept paying, I realized that not all are compatible to my watch. And finally, I realized that the sane way to look for new watch faces is to stick to the included apps in the watch suggested list within the app store inside the watch. Install others on phone and hope to use on phone will often cause a huge waste of time and money with suboptimal experience.

6. Battery life is the deal breaker. Does not last even half-day.

All in all, I am not just saying what is right or wrong with this watch, but the overall experience.
I absolutely love this watch. Since it came out I've been wanting this specific model and it finally went on sale plus the payment option made it a no brainier

This is a very nice looking watch and if not horrible battery life i would leave them, however after testing them for a few days i came to conclusion that i won't be able to keep them.
I tried using this watches with iPhone.
1) Quickly my favorite mode became the custom mode, where i would leave only certain things needs for watch to last as long as possible. However after changing features, the watch changes the mode without telling you and then you screwed.
2) At first i tried using both Bluetooth and Wi-Fi mode and the battery would drain in just couple hours
3) I then disabled WiFi, as the phone suggested and tried using only with Bluetooth.
Using with built-in watch faces, the phone would last at most half a day.

Once smartwatch goes below 30% it stops being a smart-watch and goes into extended mode, which is good if you are away from home and want to extend your battery life, but for any normal person who wants to use smart features, this is useless.
4) There are about 50 watch faces, but only 1 has seconds, which don't show up in the DIm mode.
The Facer App is great and it has nice watch faces and my own Design2 has seconds, but Facer restricts seconds in DIM mode as they say to save on battery life.
5) Using a Walk Mode to count steps with GPS turned on for 20 minutes, drained 10-15% of battery life.
If I don't want the GPS being turned on, then a valid question why do i need to pay $170 for the feature which i am afraid to use so that battery won't drain?!!
6) Another test of Bluetooth and Wifi and I lost 25% in 2 hours with watches only being in the dim mode. Comparing side-by-side with my old Sony Smartwatch3 which is still at 91% vs this new cool watch at 75% is making me nervous.
Should I know bring additional charger with me and check the battery life every half an hour?
That's not what i want.
I saw in other reviews that people were able to get thru the whole day, but in my opinion it is possible only in the extended mode, without any connection to the phone.
So yes, if you only want to count steps and check your BPM, this watches will probably last a full day.
But if you want to check text messages and emails and do even anything in the non-dim mode, the battery will drain on your eyes.
The last few days before returning the watches i tried only using them for basic needs and the watches hardly lasted for 8 hours.
My needs are 15 hours a day and the watch can't handle it.
Very unfortunate, because the watch is very nice looking with nice interface but not for the needs of an active person who needs them for more than 8 hours.

I have been using this watch regularly for about a month now. I have tried out all the features from the description so far and they all work very well.  I give great praises to this watch and would recommend it to anyone looking for a well rounded fully featured watch without the need for mobile calls, texts, etc. independent of having their phone on or near them.

That said there are only two minor issues I have with the watch.  First is battery life with all the features enabled. (This is a common issue with smartwatches.)  The watch will last just about a full day.  I suspect that over the two to three years of expected use that the battery will degrade to the point where it works for about a half a day.  I have had this happen with my previous smartwatches and it ended up restricting usage to the point where I rarely wore it.  The other issue war that I experienced an instance of disablement.  This was fixed with a reboot of the watch by pressing down on the crown (main button) for about 10-15 seconds until it vibrated, while it was charging on the charger.

Again, this watch is great.  I highly recommend it if you want a smartwatch with these features in 2020.  It's arguably the best Android Wear watch for value as of this writing.  I just have a hard time giving any "smartwatch" that's out there today a 5 star rating as the tech used in these devices isn't quite mature enough yet to grant one yet.

I'm on a mission to try out a couple different smart watches so I can pick a new daily driver. My first watch was the Fitbit Luxe (technically more of a fitness watch) and it had very little features, the app was garbage, and that fitness tracking wasn't that great which is the reason why I bought it. So I sent it back and bought the Gen 5 Carlyle.

Pros:
- Uses Wear OS so you have access to a bunch of great apps
- Completely waterproof (the Fitbit had to be out into "water lock" if you wanted it to be waterproof)
- Pretty responsive once I de-cluttered it and got rid of some bloat ware
- Can reassign the hardware buttons to go to whatever app you want
- Layout is relatively easy to use

Cons:
- Really really really bad battery life. If I use it normally throughout the day it's usually needs charged around the afternoon which sucks
- Heart rate monitor sucks. Have to have it in the perfect position on your wrist in order for it to work which means it's probably not gonna track your HR while you work out.
- Notifications show up in the notification center but I don't get actually notified with vibration or a tone most of the time. Sometimes it works sometimes it doesn't

Conclusion:
If you can get it at a discounted price I think it's a great BUDGET option. There's a new generation for these watches but from what I've heard not much have changed unfortunately. It's better than the Fitbit Luxe by A LOT though. Gonna send it back and try out the Galaxy watch next.

This watch does everything, for a limited amount of time. It probably only has about an hour or two of actual usage time. Fortunately, it's a watch, so you aren't using it constantly.

I really wanted to use this for sleep tracking, so usually I charge it before bed, and by the time I wake up it's at 75%. From there I go to school/work all day. Depending on the day, and how much time I charge it before I leave, it lasts until some time after 5pm. Basically I have to charge it once or twice a day most days - sometimes when I get home, and always before bed. That's the story of the awful battery.

Besides the awful battery this watch does everything. I've gotten many compliments on the Google Pay functionality. That and the notifications are my favorite parts. The knob for scrolling feels very nice, as do the other two buttons. Can't really say anything bad about the watch.

WearOS could use some work however, maybe some optimization to help with the battery life, but mostly just app support. I use Textra for texting, but Textra doesn't support WearOS, so if I want to text from my watch I have to change apps, which I'm not willing to do. For now, I can just reply to messages through notifications. It also seems like I should be able to open apps on my phone from all notifications, not just certain ones. At least I can be pretty certain that I will receive future updates, as the watch is cutting edge right now.

Overall, this thing is awesome. Using it feels like something out of a sci-fi film. Would absolutely buy again.

I've had the phone for about 3 weeks now and love it!

These are in no particular order. Hope this helps!

Pros
1) Display is beautiful
2) Speed is very responsive
3) The watch bezel allow you to navigate the menu quickly
**4) Battery life. To get a day or 2 out of this watch certain features need to be checked and turned of. The heart rate sensor has pulsing green lights. When you 1st get this these are constantly taking a reading also killing the battery.
A) You have to turn the Heart-rate sensor Always-on setting OFF in Google Fit. This was not inuitive
B) Most of the time my GPS is Off unless I'm using the Map App
C) Set your battery settings to custom so you can control whats using your battery
*D) When you 1st get this the life of the battery sucks. after 4  or 5 charges it will balance out to 1 to 2 days of use before charging.
E) I have my brightness set to the highest at 5 and I don't see a significant drain on the battery. I don't really like the auto brightness feature.

5)  Love having Google Maps on my wrist!
6) Google assistant can answer questions and navigate the watch(sometimes).
7) Easily connects to the phone. I am personally using the Mate 10 Pro.
8) The Metal clasp one act as a stand and you can have the charging puck tucked in the middle.

Cons:

1) There is a learning curve and its mostly the software
2) You have to update Android Wear and the play store out of the box.
3) Google Assistant will not navigate all watch features and menus but most.
4) Play store is limited but there is a mini YouTube app, compass, maps and fitness apps available
5) Speaker quality. Good for music. Static-y for phone calls. ( I still need to mess with these to see if I'm doing something wrong) but the few calls I made were horrendous yet they said I sounded fine on their end.
6) Hope the Android Wear ecosystem gets better.

Love this watch! It feels nice like a quality watch. I have received multiple complements when wearing it as it actually looks like a watch not some mini computer on your arm.
Fossil has been great with updates when I first opened the watch and set it up I had to update it a few times and it took a while but that just shows that fossil is keeping up support.
The battery life could be better. I wear it to work and I do 10-13 hour shifts by the time I hit 8-9 hours the watch is already is battery saver mode so I have to charge it every night. But it hasn’t died on me during a shift yet.
My only complaint is that when I switched to iPhone this watch caused a lot of issues with the iPhone. When it worked what it could do was limited but it was still usable. Most of the time I was having issues because it would disconnect from Bluetooth and wouldn’t want to reconnect this would also cause other Bluetooth devices to have issues connecting. I would have to turn Bluetooth off and on and forget the devices and re connect them. Most of the time that would work but sometimes I would have to restart the phone. I stopped using the watch.
Great smart watch for android horrible issues with iPhone.

The elephant in the room: battery life.
If I can get 16-18 hours, that's long enough to get it back on the charger when I go to bed. More is better but a watch must meet this minimum standard. This watch manages that and a little more, especially if I keep app usage to a minimum.

I demand two things from a smartwatch: the time and discreet notifications for messages, emails, and calls on my phone. Weather at a glance is nice, too. I don't want to use my watch as a speakerphone or music player and I certainly don't want to have it giving me constant turn by turn prompts from Google Maps. Heart rate and step tracking are useful but I haven't worn a watch while sleeping since I was in the Army three decades ago so sleep tracking is lost on me.

In terms of capabilities, this watch is overkill for me but it looks nice and the Prime Day price was too good to pass up. My only major gripe is the dangerously exposed glass bezel. It sits up above the body of the watch and is easily cracked (this is not my first Carlyle HR). I strongly recommend a TPU or silicone cover/bumper to protect the glass.

All in all, it is a good replacement for my LG G Watch R, which died after several years of rugged and reliable service

As a software developer, I get great enjoyment out of this watch. It's sleep tracking and heart monitoring abilities are fantastic and I, someone who has only ever worn pajamas to bed, have been able to sleep with it on with zero issue. Battery life is a drain for me because I like to use all the features but, if you turn all that off you could definitely get two-days use. I'm excited to potentially take this camping and be able to leave the phone in the car!

It's sleek design is handsome out of the box, and it's beauty is only slightly hidden by the plastic "suit of armor" case i bought for it. I don't know how resistant the screen is to scratches and cracks and I'm not keen to find out, but the touch screen has no issue with a screen cover. Just take the cover off if you have to hop on a video call or take a selfie!

My last thoughts are that I wouldn't expect much in terms of quantity of apps. If you don't care about health tracking, or the watch's functionality, and are only interested in new apps, I wouldn't have FOMO if you don't have a Smartwatch, and would advise you wait a couple more years for more apps to enter the market.

Use it for last 4 months. Have very mixed feelings. From one hand it has many advantages, but disadvantages just kill customer experience. Support (does it exist?) is not responsive. Now a bit about pros and cons.
Advantages:
- nice looking. It is very subjective of course, but it is one of the best looking smart watches (for my taste)
- durable. By coincidence I was hitting or scratching different surfaces by this watch, they kept it well, screen is still like new
- fast charge. Comparing to Galaxy Active 2 this charges are least twice as fast
- different battery modes. One can easily switch between them and chose high performance or saving battery

Ok things:
- battery life. Improved from gen 4 and similar to other rivals
- there are some apps. Not too many, but some are useful

Disadvantages:
- Bluetooth connection. It sucks. Sometimes they are connected, sometimes they disconnect. When you try to switch it back, it is not enough (like manual says) just to tap on Bluetooth connection and then phone. Instead one has to switch off and on Bluetooth, sometimes several times. Sometimes you have to open app on phone and then it connects.
- no sleep tracking. They (producers) can’t make sleep tracking!!! 20$ watch have it but this don’t!
- GPS sucks. One of the main purposes I bought this watch was to be able to run without phone. This is almost impossible. If you are lucky GPS will connect after 15 minutes, if not - never without your phone, only when you are home and connected to a cell phone.
- APP on a phone. Piece of crap. Connection is not stable. Integration between watch and phone is weird - you update, it says it is updated, but steps count on watch and phone are different. Activities can upload for more than a day, although app says it is synced, what the hack?

As a conclusion. I’d you like style and look of this watch and do not plan to use it for lots of sport activities - take them, you most probably will be very happy. If you like to use it for sports, sleep tracking - consider another model.

Ps. I use them with my IPhone. Maybe Android would allow more, but Apple doesn’t allow much :(
Unfortunately I hate Apple Watch and it is problematic to find watches supported by iOS.

This is my 3rd Android/Google smartwatch, and the first one that I purchased brand new.
I've been using this watch for just a little over a month now and I'm very pleased with it as a replacement for my LG Urbane2. I never had a SIM card in the LG so battery life was never an issue with the larger battery it had.
I only upgraded mainly for 2 reasons, first the microphone died, and second the watch band was breaking. I purchased the LG "refurbished" for $100 and was really happy with it, but since the mic was bad and it was going to cost around$75 for a replacement band it was time to upgrade.

The LG was purchased to replace the original Moto 360 I bought used because the battery was failing again. The original lasted over a year for me, the replacement fell just shy of a year. Plus it was an upgrad adding a speaker and the ability to use Google pay on the watch.

I wear this watch daily and usually have at least 10% battery life left when I put it in the charger at night. Battery life in I  a custom mode with everything turned on except Ok Google detection.

This watch so far is just superior to both of my previous smart-watches. My only apprehension buying was to he smaller battery capacity compared to what it replaced. However this makes the watch thinner on my wrist, and for me the size is great! I love that I can use any 22mm standard band on it and change it out easily. That was a big downfall of both of it's predecessors for me requiring special bands.

I am by no means a heavy user of the watch. I have been wearing a watch for about 30 years now, I never could adjust to just using my phone.
This for me as an automotive technician is great because I don't have to take my gloves off or get grease all over my phone just to see who is calling or texting at that moment. For me the smart-watches are an extension of the phone, and it's great for getting notifications without having to keep the phone in my pocket.

Three weeks ago I purchased 2 highly rated Wear OS watches, the Fossil Gen 5 Carlyle and a Ticwatch Pro 4G LTE (to be paired with my Pixel phone). The Fossil was intended to be my daily driver, worn to my full time job as a teacher and also going on volunteer Fire/EMS calls during my work days. As an EMT there's one feature of this watch's 3100 chipset that I particularly like: you can get watch faces that have a moving sweep second hand even when the always on display is asleep or dimmed. This is something most smartwatches can't do and it's really important for taking patients' vital signs.

Overall, I really like this watch. It's essentially my "dress" watch, as opposed to the larger Ticwatch Pro. The Fossil is relatively thin and looks good on my small-ish wrist. The included silicon band isn't great, though. It's a dust/ lint magnet. My use case is mostly for notifications. I don't use the activity tracker features much, other than the step counter and rarely the heart rate sensor. I do have the always on screen enabled as well as the lift to wake option, but not NFC. With those settings I usually end a16 hour day with about 33% battery left. I don't use sleep tracking and I charge it every night.

The Fossil's swim rating makes me comfortable wearing it in wet environments. I am a bit concerned about screen protection, though. The glass is not protected by a bezel and it's apparently not Gorilla Glass, either. Fossil told me it's "alkali-aluminosilicate sheet glass commonly used in conumer electronics." That's what Gorilla Glass is, so this may be a competing company's product?

There is a software glitch with this watch. There's an option to turn on Do Not Disturb when the watch is off your wrist. This does work. However, it doesn't turn Do Not Disturb off when you put the watch back on, so you miss notifications. I just turned this option off.

In conclusion, the Fossil Gen 5 is a stylish smartwatch that will easily get you through the day with light/moderate use and the added benefit of always having a sweep second hand visible if you need that for healthcare or some other reason. Recommended.

One of the main things I was concerned about getting a Wear OS watch was batter life. So many reviewers of so many models complained that their watch would last the day. I use the custom settings to save on battery life, with a few things I don't need like GPS and always on display turned off. I do have NFC and the heart rate monitor turned on. The watch easily lasts the day. I put it on the charger at night while getting ready for bed, and it charges quickly, so I usually pull if off the charger at 90% to extend the battery's life. Even only charging to 90% and leaving it all night, it easily lasts the next day.

I love the customizable buttons. I have the top one set to Google Pay, so paying for things is super quick and easy -- no scrolling through apps to get into Google Pay. The bottom button takes me straight to my workout timer.

Before getting this, I hadn't worn a watch for years, since my phone can give me the time, and I preferred not having a bulky thing strapped to my wrist. This watch is thin enough that it doesn't bug me.

The band was probably nicer than most, but I replaced it anyway (with a magnetic closure metal mesh one, which adjusts to literally any size and breathes well while working out.) One thing I love about both the original and replacement bands is that no tools are required to remove or install them. So you can get multiple bands and switch between them to match whatever occasion.

The OS has been extremely stable. This morning was the first time I ever had to restart it in a month and half. (It was showing the time, but not unlocking for some reason.)

I love that the watch face is customizable. I actually created my own face in Facer with my company logo and a nice clean design with just the elements I want on it.

Finally, before getting a smart watch, I was a little skeptical about how much more convenient it would be to check messages and the time on a watch vs. a phone. I am no longer skeptical. It is so convenient.

Sorry, fans of the watch from that "other" company: REAL watches are ROUND.  This watch is round.

I have to say, I love the style of this watch--it's genuine Fossil, and looks sharp.  I had to go with the leather band (whose dark brown color goes surprisingly well with the black watch), but I am looking at buying the steel watchband for it since I find those more comfortable.  I also own an LG G Watch R in rose gold that looks nice, but the hardware is a few years old now and it's not as snappy as it used to be.  But, it is still more than capable.  The Fossil is a nice change, and the black case is a nice alternative to the LG!

What I like?  The buttons on the side do something, even the "stem" that can be rotated in one direction for notifications and in the other for settings.  And as I said, the style of it is high quality without looking pretentious (and it's not a ridiculous "rounded square").  There are plenty of Fossil-designed watch faces that can be installed and customized.  (I like using Facer, but their app has gotten bloated and drags down the OS on any watch I have tried it on.)  Apps are snappy.  I don't use the voice features, but it's interesting that is now has a tiny speaker.

What I don't like?  Battery life is not good.  Unless I need to use this a lot more to somehow "calibrate" the battery and the OS, I can't see this lasting throughout a day.  Although I admit that I was playing with the watch quite a bit right after I got it.  Still, after 20-30 minutes, I don't expect battery life to have dipped into the sub-90% range.  Also, the charging pad is rather small.  The LG has a nice, large magnetic base that it sits within.  This is just a small magnetic charging pad that the Fossil perches on top of.

It's a keeper, though! I'm glad I purchased this one on sale, and am looking forward to receiving the steel watch band for it.

So I have been looking for a good Android alternative.  Decided to take a chance on the Fossil after considering it with the Armani 3.  Now I exercise daily, walking and every 4 days add 30 - 40 minutes of weightlifting.  I also own a Series 5 Watch and a couple of Garmins and never have a problem getting all day from Apple or multiple days with Garmin.  So the first day with Fossil I put it on at 6:30AM.  Lifted weights first for 34 minutes then went out for a 4.2 mile walk.  When I finished the walk I noticed the battery life was down to 57%.  So I went in to notifications and turned off everything but two.  Left the AOD on (can only dumb it down so much).  At 2:30 PM the watch was completely dead.  Put it on the charger for the rest of the day.  Day two I went in and customized the battery settings and turned off as much as I could.  Put it back on the charger to get it back to 100% before walking.  So back on the wrist at 6:45am, 5 minute drive to where I was walking.  Did a 5.4 mile walk, just under 90 minutes.  Checked the battery again  and noticed the watch was down to 53%.  Day two actually lasted a little longer.  Watch completely shutdown at 4:15 PM.  So I wanted to see how it would do with music and exercise so I added a Playlist and setup my Jaybird Vistas on the watch for day three.  Day 3 made sure battery was at 100% before the short drive for my walk and put it on at 6:50AM.  Day 3 walked 4.5 miles 78 minutes with music and GPS.  Checked the battery at the end which was down to 41%.  Watch was completely drained at11:50AM.  I could probably go into settings and make some changes to probably extend this for a couple of hours, but it seems kind of pointless because now I have a Smartwatch not doing anything.  Short battery life seems to be kind of common with Android watches right now.  I am not really sure if this is due to Wear OS not being optimized yet or if it is the hardware that vendors are using.  So all day for me would typically be from around 5:00AM to 10:00PM at night. Even if I could get the Fossil to the Evening hours I would consider keeping it, but routinely completely dead in the afternoon has me returning this.  Really hoping that Google takes the Smartwatch business seriously this year and comes out with something nice.

Delivery and package
-Good time
-Closed package (new), good but it was not tighten to the amazon box.

After +4 days of use,
SmartWatch, first impressions:
- Good looking box and watch
- Quality materials
- Fits good and is comfortable, not heavy

First use and configuration:
- Serious troubles to first time pair and update with phone (android), restarted like 3 times.
- No clear indications in the phone or app, how to pair and configure, no able to restart the process without reset everything, quite frustrating, not way to go back and retry need to reset the watch.
- Should came with a wall charger, first act for a user is find a cellphone charger to charge the watch, but after a deep review in some comments is mentioned that is not recommended to use a charger, depends on the charger type. Hope buyers be careful with that, I wil always charge with computer.
- Lack of instructions to configure, almost everything is based on experiences, just few tips when start.
- Intuitive and simple to use, but would be best if could be configure according with user needs.
- Lack of configurable options in slide screens, just a few and limited.
- Very good variety of watches backgrounds.
- Battery life not as expected (First day 2 recharges, second day 1 recharge, switching on modes, mostly in extended mode both days, hope gets better in time, soon)
- Preloaded APPs, my first impressions seems some ones which don’t know what they do so, know that there are some drivers or things to make phone works or other apps, but would rather have the choice to install them or not, still figure it out if could be removed or if they are needed.
-There are better apps to be included instead of those preloaded.
- Lack of file management (require app), need to deep dive into apps for phone and watch to keep things moving.
-Performance seems good response, sometimes is a lag to touch response but is minimum.
-Good response to wifi signal, but would be great to have a way to connect to signal that requires open a explorer or something else to access (eg. hotel wifi).
- Exterior buttons are pretty good, but might be good to have extended uses (add more features to them)
- Rom is good, available above 4 gb, seems fair for a watch, thinking
- Voice recognition is regular, first time I try to give commands didn’t work, after a while it work but lagging response and not clearly identify what I say, I will keep testing the feature, hope there is everthing fine with the watch.

I will give 3 starts, because it hasn't met my expectations, there are things still to probe and hope some of them improve with the use, so far I think is a good smartwatch.
Video Player is loading.

Yes, by all accounts it should work with iPhone, even if with limited functionality, but it doesn't work consistently.  I keep the app open in the background, but it still loses sync multiple times throughout the day and I have to turn bluetooth off on the watch and back on before it finally syncs back up.  And you have to sync it with the app and the phone, so you'll see 2 entries of the watch connected in your bluetooth settings.  If you don't sync it with the phone also, you don't get notifications and stuff.  I never could get the heart rate monitor working.  Features seem to be not supported on iOS.  So I do not recommend this for iPhone.

However, I gave it to my wife to try on her Android and it worked great for her.  Kept track of her steps, heart rate, sleep... everything I wanted the watch to do worked for her.  The watch itself is gorgeous, the screen is great, the band is a soft rubber that feels good on the wrist (I also got a metal band to swap out when I want to look fancy).  I really loved this watch and wished it would have worked on my iPhone better.  That's not entirely Fossil and WearOS's fault.  Apple purposefully locks down their stuff to make it as hard on 3rd party companies to offer quality products that work on iOS as possible so users are forced to buy Apple products, as I have been forced to buy an Apple Watch instead in order to get full functionality with my iPhone.  If you have Android, I can't recommend this watch enough.  If you have Apple, try elsewhere.

Pros:
- Great battery life. My screen is not always on, only wakes up when I tilt the watch. This way I can easily get 1.5-2 days per charging.
- Nice look and feel. Not too big. The leather bands give it a really nice look. Received many compliments that it looks nice and is similar to a real watch.
- Really good screen size and resolution. The pictures in IMs, search results, etc. are very detailed and useful even on such a small screen.
- Very good synchronization with the phone. The alerts appear on the phone and watch almost the same time. The dismissed notifications also disappear on the phone.
- A lot of good apps

Cons:
- The touchscreen is very fragile. I scratched it on the second day of wearing it. It's really frustrating, because I was wearing a smart fitness watch for the past 4 years, which never got sratched. So beware: get a protective foil, glass or case over the screen.
- Charging is very difficult. The charging pad snaps to the back of the clock, but 9 times out of 10 it doesn't start charging. Most days I need to fiddle with it for 5-10 minutes until it finally starts to charge. Even then, sometimes it stops charging around 80%.
- The big middle button sticks out and I always accidentally long press it, starting the Google Assistant voice command recognition. Sometimes I press even longer and accidentally switch off the clock (e.g.: during exercising).
- The system sounds/chimes are very poor quality. For example, the notification of the start of charging, or when an alarm goee off, the watch sounds like a mobile phone from the 90's. Definitely not like a nice smart watch like this should sound. This is probably the fault of WearOS and could be customized, but would be nice to have it out of the box.
- Sleep tracker is not included by default.

Conclusion:
I'm using it for a bit less than a month and am really happy with the watch.
My wife has a series 3 Apple watch and this Fossil watch seems to be at the same level in speed and functionality. The Fossil's battery life seems to be a lot better. I also think that this watch can display more text on its screen than the series 3 Apple watch.
So if you can live with the cons listed above, I definitely recommend purchasing it.

I was on the fence wanting to buy the ticwatch pro 2020 given it's more innovative display and battery claims.  This went on sale significantly cheaper so is it a good smartwatch?  Yes it is.

The Positive: The screen has excellent fidelity.  It's the most clearly handsome smartwatch.
Their is no real lag in the apps which was a frequent complaint on wear os devices.  Replying to messages sent via different apps via voice or text on the watch is nice.

The Bad:  Wear OS has a very small catalog of apps.  Battery in extended mode only lasts a day and a half of moderate use.  Regular mode is good for about a day.  While in extended apps like the weather don't function.  You would just use it to check and reply to various notifications and check time.

Note: If you don't normally wear a watch and we're looking at getting the metal banded version be aware you will most likely need to take links out and buy one of those hammer and push pin kits to take out the links. They run around 12 bucks on Amazon.

Prior to buying this I was curious how this or even if this would work with my companies work profile on my phone.  There isn't much data on this on the internet.  My company chose not to approve the wear os app on their profile so some options are limited.  The Microsoft Teams app notifications that pop up when people message you do pop up on the watch.  You can respond to those messages with voice to text responses.  I was pretty pleased in at least that win. You will not be able to sync the companies calendar appointments etc though.  Hope that helps.

Overall I like the watch.  I do find myself wishing it had some of the features (for batteries sake) of the newest ticwatch but do enjoy the look of this one more.

Had the watch for a long time. I use it as my daily watch.

It's durable. I find myself banging it against door frames and other things pretty often, and it has no damage.

It's actually waterproof. I've taken it swimming, and have taken it about 12ft deep in water, and never had any issues. The water did not activate the touchscreen, and the dials and buttons worked fine.

The battery life is a bit disappointing. You need to pick and choose which settings you want on in order to have the watch last throughout the entire day. My biggest suggestion is to turn off any gesture controls, because they get accidentally activated so often that it kills your battery life.

WearOS is the biggest problem with the watch. It's kinda buggy, the menus are annoying to go through, and the settings are lacking.

For watch faces, I suggest finding an app that you can design your own, or download other custom made faces. I use Facer to make my own digital watchface.

Notifications come in at the same time as your phone. There isn't any delay between your phone vibrating and your watch vibrating.

However, sometimes the watch will disconnect from Bluetooth for no reason. It's not often, maybe once a month or so, but it's happened enough that I can bring it up in this review.

Also the brightness settings are absolutely trash. You have the option of 1 through 5, 1 being the dimmest, 5 being the brightest, but unless you're only using the watch at night, you need to keep it on the brightest setting at all times. I also find it really hard to see in direct sunlight.

Also to note: replace the watch strap it comes with. If you get sweaty, it starts to stink really bad.

...Well... this watch changed my mind.

It would actually be 5 stars except for the fact sometimes my watch loses sync with my phone.  But that happens with my car and phone too so maybe it's my phone. Huh. (EDIT - changed it to five stars because it turns out it WAS my phone that was losing sync and not the watch.) Well anyways yeah I never thought smartwatches made any sense whatsoever, especially not at $300+. But then this bad boy went on sale for under $210 and I am one of those people who always misses phone calls, txts, and emails because I lay my phone down and forget about it. Yeah my life does not revolve around a phone. But with the coronavirus lockdown I needed to be instantly reachable for work since I'm working from home right now. Yet I hate carrying my phone around when I'm at home. So a small device that I can wear on my person that instantly lets me know when someone is trying to reach me AND i can txt and take phone calls on it?! PERFECT.

And this bad boy IS perfect. Although when doing my research I kept reading how Samsung watches have so much better battery life, what Samsung watches *don't* have is Google assistant. And Samsung's speech-to-text is HORRIBLE. My wife's Note 9 cannot understand what I'm saying u-n-l-e-s-s I t-a-l-k s-l-o-w l-i-k-e I h-a-v-e s-p-e-c-i-a-l n-e-e-d-s, but my Huawei Mate SE *perfectly* translates my everyday speech to text - even when i've got loud music playing. And since I'm not trying to type on a tiny 1" screen, that only leaves me the option of buying a watch whose speech-to-text actually works or else I have to go find my phone again. Nah. So I bought this watch and after the first two days the battery life improved drastically (usually end with anywhere from 20% to 40% after a 16-hr day. Like right now it's after 10pm and I still have 48% left. Pro Tip: turn the screen off while watching TV.) And it understands my speech-to-text needs perfectly. Best of all, it has Google assistant so it seamlessly works with all my google stuff.

Now my boss can call and I always pick up. I see emails immediately and can respond to the ones that actually need an immediate response, and same for txts.

As for the health/heartbeat functions I'm not into all that, so never use them.

All-in-all I am very happy with my smartwatch purchase, even though I am probably about to be laid off and can't afford it haha. Too late! I already love it so it stays.

I bought this specifically because I needed Wear OS integration. I have Type 1 Diabetes and wear an electronic device to continuously monitor my blood sugar, a Dexcom G6 CGM, and that only works with iOS or Wear OS. Otherwise, I might have chosen another watch, but this was one of the best of the Wear OS ones, although I considered a couple of MobvoiTicWatch watches.

So far, the features I use and can comment on:

- I can see my blood glucose measurements on my watch at all times, which is why I needed Wear OS. This is fantastic. It relies on Bluetooth between the watch and has been reliable unless I am separated by multiple concrete walls.

- The message integration is nice and keeps me alerted, and when I have 2-factor authentication for a site, I get the code on my watch, which is way more convenient than reaching for the phone. It is convenient to get my messages on the watch, and usually just swipe them away, or if interested, respond. It does transcribe verbal messages well.

- I have taken calls on my watch, which is nice but can also be surprising if unexpected

- I use the heart rate monitoring for my rowing and running workouts, which integrates with Google Fit. I'm not obsessed about the accuracy but the number lines up with my other heart rate monitor, a Scosche Rhythm 24. I use third-party apps to synchronize my Polar Beat and Withings BF Scale with Google Fit.

- Throughout the day I use Google Assistant, the countdown timers, the stopwatch, the UV Index app, Google Breathe (this is nice)

- I am enjoying sleep tracking to get a sense of how many hours of rest I am getting. (Sleep was added later in 9/2020, as part of a Wellness App update).

Quibbles

- The usual is the battery, but I generally get a full day with moderately active use, although if I'm very busy, I charge it while wearing one of my older watches. Charging is very fast.

- Occasionally, I need to swipe twice if it doesn't recognize it, but that could be me.

- On a few occasions, Google Assistant didn't respond, so I either turned it off then on or simply pressed the assistant icon and spoke then.

Update 9/6/20: after a major update, fossil now includes a wellness app that can do a lot of things that the watch was missing when it first came out – now it is a much more useful and versatile watch and I am bumping it up to four out of five stars. It still could use a bit better battery life, but it has gotten a bit better after the update.
------------
I bought this watch because it has been consistently touted as the best smartwatch outside the Samsung/Apple ecosystems. If it is, having had a Galaxy watch, I can say that does not bode well for any brands besides the duopoly. That being said, it's a decent watch, just that you're really paying for brand on this one.

As a lot of others have said, the battery life leaves something to be desired - however, coming from older Galaxy watches a day and a half to two days is what I'm used to. I was thinking if I switched from the anemic Tizen ecosystem to Wear OS I'd have a plethora of things to run on my watch, but the Wear OS app store is as anemic as any of the other proprietary ones, though that's not on Fossil.

The controls are decent and the ability to program the side buttons is nice. The watch strap and back don't bother me, which is usually an issue so if you have sensitive skin, this doesn't bother a guy that can't wear surgical steel for the minute amount of nickel in it. I do really like that the straps are interchangeable, I have a few straps I've used with the watch so definitely a plus.

The voice functions and speaker are okay. As long as you're not out in traffic or on a loud construction site you can hear what's coming out of it. Good enough for "can you pick up some bread while you're at the store" conversations and using Assistant, not so much anything else. And it's especially annoying to bump the crown, which is both a button and a knob, and hear my watch say I'm sorry I didn't hear you and find out that assistant has been sitting on.

All in all, it's an okay watch. I'd definitely pay $120 for it, but not the $233 it was at when I bought it. Wear OS still has some maturing to do as a platform if it wants to play alongside the S/A duopoly because they really do have everyone beat.

The watch had functioned normally after I purchased it, but three months later, it stopped working entirely. Running its battery flat and connecting the adapter clearly indicated that it could charge as the watch would flash a charging indicator, but it would not do anything else and would soon stop even that. I had not subjected the watch to any possibly damaging situations. For instance, I never got it wet even though it's water resistant, nor did I subject it to shocks. The failure appears to be a quality assurance problem, although the specific cause in my case remains unknown. I reported this issue to the manufacturer, which covered the repair as it was still under warranty (one year). This process took a month or so, and it seems they replaced most or all of the components (the serial number has changed).
