The replacement watch has arrived very recently and is functioning well so far. If it experiences any problems, I will update this review.
This paragraph is about the software used by Fossil, Wear OS by Google, but is not specific to this particular watch. The operating system has several significant defects. The first is that, although it has the ability to use WiFi networks, it frequently decides that it's just not going to. The settings for WiFi are off and automatic, and automatic mode frequently means that it thinks it doesn't need to be connected right now. This meant that apps that used WiFi would either take several seconds to connect or would experience a large delay before informing me that no network was available. WiFi isn't needed if the watch is being used for time, notifications from a phone, or fitness tracking, but it would be for most complex apps. There used to be a developer setting that would prevent the automatic system disabling WiFi, but it has been removed. This is serious, as development virtually requires WiFi to synchronize data between the development computer and the test device, which is frequently broken. Similarly, connection to a paired phone over Bluetooth was spotty, and when it wasn't connected, it showed a notification about that often. I didn't use many features requiring a stable connection, but the constant notification was irritating. If you want a smartwatch in order to run complex applications, this platform will likely frustrate you, since most important functionality requires a network connection. For example, you can use dictation to type, but only if you're online. Otherwise you can try to type on a full QWERTY keyboard displayed on a watch screen, which is difficult. There are two programmable buttons, which are nice, but Wear Os only lets you use those buttons to launch applications. If you want a fast launch, that's great, but the system also puts the most recent three apps launched on the home screen so it's already easy. You can't map those buttons to specific features inside apps or to simulated key presses. If you use a degoogled AOSP-based Android, this watch won't work with it, or at all. It won't set itself up without the Wear OS app, and if you sideload that, it will complain and exit on startup. You have to install the app on an IOS or normal Android device for it to work, though a Google account isn't required. If you don't know what I just said, the situation probably doesn't apply to you.
When functioning, this watch ran as expected. Battery life was about two days when not used intensively and with power-intensive features like always-on screen disabled, but would fall behind if called upon to do other tasks. If you intend to use a Wear OS watch, expect to charge it every day. Audio quality is surprisingly good for such a small speaker, with loud sound output possible. Location from the GPS/GLONASS chip was generally accurate but took a long time to initialize and dramatically affected battery life.
In conclusion, proceed with caution only if you understand and accept the limits. One anecdote doesn't constitute a study on resilience, but there may be problems with the hardware. Meanwhile, the software has limits which cannot be circumvented. If you don't need compatibility with Wear OS apps, you may not want to use this. If you are developing wearable apps, you have Samsung's Tizen and Apple's Watch OS as alternative platforms.

The watch looks really nice in person and very classy on the wrist. The first day I wore it I received a random compliment from a bank teller who had no idea it was a even a smartwatch until I told her. So I definitely give it 5 stars for appearance, especially with all the cool watch faces you can choose from, download, or even custom make using 3rd party apps!

Unfortunately, the native Google Fit app doesn't have the capabilities to monitor sleep tracking so you'll need to download and integrate a 3rd party app (such as 'Sleep As Android'). This was slightly inconvenient, but at least it works once you set it up and Google has done a good job of making it easy to integrate many 3rd party apps into Google Fit. However, it should be noted that while your watch can help capture your sleep data, you still won't be able to access your sleep data on the Google Fit app on your watch. Instead, that data will only be made visible on the Google Fit app on your phone. This is another slight inconvenience which is why I only gave the sleep tracking capabilities 3 stars at the end of the day.

The battery life is easily good enough to last you the entire day and even longer if you use the battery saving features and don't use it for making calls, playing music and other things that obviously require additional battery life. I personally like to utilize a lot of the watch features, including wearing it overnight for sleep tracking, so I have to designate some time each day to recharge it. Thankfully, the watch recharges extremely fast (20 minutes or less) so I gave it 5 stars for battery life.

The watch uses Google Wear OS as the native mobile app which is very easy and straightforward to use. You're able to change the watch settings, watch faces, connect accounts, and basically all the standard administrative tasks can be done within the app. Plus I have a Google Pixel phone so I'm not sure if that makes it any easier. I decided to give it 5 stars since the app basically does what I'd expect it to do with a clean interface.

Overall, I gave the watch 4 stars just because of its inability to do certain things out the box without 3rd party apps. However, if you're willing to take the time to set it up you'll be able to customize it the way you want. Besides that, the smartwatch looks like a classy timepiece that will get attention. It also charges fast and has all the bells & whistles of any other smartwatch on the market. For the price I'd say this Fossil watch is a great option!

So far after a week I can say this watch is a joy to use.  This is a big upgrade on my old Fossil Sport.  The addition of speaker and better all day heart rate detection was a big plus for me.  The additional ram also really helps the processor shine and it moves through menus much faster now.  Buttons also have a nicer feel the rotary dial middle button moves much smoother.  Fossil did a great job of upgrading this product without the expense of the battery.  I am getting probably a little more over a days charge with the AOD display on and all features on.  It has other options to extend the battery to a week and balance battery life.  Not to mention the screen is larger and the weight of the watch is still very comfortable for a middle aged man to carry.  I have not tried swimming with this watch like i did on my old sport but that watch handled normal swimming like a champ so I expect this will too.  If only Wear O.S had good swim tracking apps.

Pros For Me:
- Peppy performance very little to no lag in menu transitions
- Exceptional battery life (there are tricks to extend your battery performance) you should have no trouble making a full active day on one charge.
- Improved heart rate tracking with Caridiogram pre installed.  The watch checks my heart rate every 5 minutes and still makes a full day charge
- Easy to install your favorite watchband and inexpensive protective bumpers and screen covers can be found if your tough on your watch like I am.
- Fossil kept the same charger! So if your upgrading like me your old chargers still work and you can keep a spare in the car or office.  Thank you fossil!  Spare chargers are also inexpensive and easy to find for your travel needs.
- Great watch faces - Fossil packs  a good selection but Wear O.S in general gives you a ton of options that you can change up for mood and occasions.

Cons:
- Wear O.S is still wear o.s but it has come a long way to be more smart watch competitive.
- The Style of this watch is simplistic and not very flashy so it will not standout if that is what you are looking for
- I wish fossil would make a watch with a rotating ring around the face like some of the Samsung watches.  I would buy that watch in a heartbeat!
- I think it does sleep tracking but since you need to charge the watch at night you cant really use this feature.
- No cellular options.  I had this on my old LG smart watches and while I did not use it often it would be nice if it was a option for when you cant be near your phone.

Slow process getting to the point where forking over the dough for a Wear OS watch looked appealing. My goal: tight, trouble free integration with Google Fit, which is my favorite app for collecting and visualizing exercise, weight, and similar data.
Other solutions I tried had spotty data syncing (MiFit) or overwrote the weight data from my smart scale (VeryFitPro).
Pleased to report that using Fossil Gen 5 to track steps and walks and other exercise events sends data promptly and reliably to Google Fit both on the watch and on my phone. Weight data from my Wyze scale syncs well to Fit and nothing overwrites it.
Fossil's sleep tracker syncs fine w/Fit, but isn't all that accurate at detecting when I'm asleep and when awake... so, I'm not sure what that's worth. Sleep tracking was not a priority anyway.
Battery life is a challenge, but not bad once you get the watch customized and quit fiddling with it. The process of navigating a lot and installing apps, and other customizing eats up battery quicker than anything else. I can get 24 hours easy now and probably 2 days if I tried a little.
The black silicon band looks cool in flat black but it's a magnet for tiny bits of skin and anything else that isn't flat black.... so looks dirty most of the time. I'll be replacing that soon. It is quite comfortable though.
I have small bones, so I wear it on second to the last hole. The watch itself is a wee bit bulky but not bad. Here's to hoping that in the future the battery life doubles while the watch gets thinner. :-)  ... chances are good, eventually.
---
Update 4/14/22
It's been just over a year. The watch has held up pretty well, but I have to knock a star off, maybe two. The watch has an intermittent problem where it rapidly drains its battery for no apparent reason. In support forums, etc., others report similar problems. Theories range from wifi connection to 'just a glitch, reset the watch and you'll be fine.' The random fast drain is very fast. This morning I took it off the charger at 7:30 AM. It had about 10% battery left at noon. Usually, after restarting watcha and recharging, it's normal again for a period. Usually weeks, but sometimes only a few days.
Recently the fast drain thing happened when I was at an event, and it was a bummer to go to do a tracked walk and discover there wasn't enough power left (early afternoon).
Battery is a struggle even when it's not acting up. It makes it through day, excluding any sleep cycle. That is, there is not enough battery to get through 24 hrs. More like 16 or 18.  And with the margin so tight, if you turn on an activity that enables GPS and heart rate checking (usually I don't have that turned and don't have heart rate turned on either), then forget to turn it off when you're done...  Battery is going to be zapped way before bedtime.
So, I'm shopping for something better. Given the demands of Wear OS, you have to plan to spend more than $300 (probably a lot more) to get a battery life that will forgive imperfect power management and still get you through 24 hours. Given how I actually used the watch over the last year, it doesn't look like Wear OS and Google Fit are worth it. 99% of the features I actually use are available on fitness watches like Garmin's line with triple or quadruple the battery life. I will probably wave goodbye soon to both Wear OS and Google Fit until the tech catches up with practical realities and practical pricing.

As far as smartwatches go, this is undoubtedly the best one to buy in terms of cost/performance. I'll break down the various parts of the watch, what works, and what doesn't, and add final thoughts below. I'll be comparing this at some points to the TicWatch 2020, as it is one of the closest competitors.

Case:
The case is made of lightweight metal, and the lugs for the band are very sturdy as well. The fact that the charge contacts are rings and not points is also a plus.

Face & Bezel:
The face is clear, and easy to read, but here's where I'll be deducting some points: First, the face and screen are not exactly honest, as there is a 4mm dead ring between the bezel and true screen. I like a watch with a nice big face, and was hoping this would compare to the Ticwatch, but sadly, it does not. The lack of a raised bezel is also a bad thing, as this makes the addition of a screen protector necessary.

Power:
Fortunately, this watch supports fast charging, compared to the Ticwatch, which must be charged specifically at 5v/1a, or it will burn out. Battery life is acceptable, so long as you treat this more as a watch... Any heavy usage will mean running out of power before your day is over. The power saver mode means it doesn't turn into a complete paperweight, but a second TFT screen would be appreciated so you could still do things like step counting, as is available on the Ticwatch 2020.

Waterproofing:
The full swimmability is greatly appreciated, since for the money the last thing you want is to lose this to a fall off the dock, or getting pushed into the pool.

Band:
The band is OK, but not very good. Switch to a multilink metal band instead for better ventilation and ease of cleaning. I recommend this one, or similar: https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07GZC81MP/

Controls:
The two programmable buttons, and center crown are the most usable set of manual controls, hands down. I never get tired of using the crown to scroll through menus. This is far better than any two-button setup.

Storage:
The fact that you have almost 6gb to install apps is far and away top of the line, with most other competitors offering barely 1.5gb

Speed:
The Snapdragon 3100 makes WearOS function smoothly, with no noticeable lag when operating menus, streaming music, using your phone as a periscope or remote camera, and even playing video. The low power cores mean ambient mode does not flicker, even with a full color screen.

Sensors:
The heart rate sensor seems to be accurate, and off-body detection works. Tap and Pay works as expected.

Features I'd like to see in a future version:
Bigger screen that is truly what size it claims to be, hopefully as big as the Ticwatch screen.
Dual screen (like the Ticwatch) for low power mode.
Raised bezel, for protection without the need for a screen protector.
Left Handed Mode

Overall, this is one of the best options out there, with the only major issues being the false screen size, and lack of a raised bezel. If you want a smaller screen, this watch will meet your needs nicely.

I spent a lot of time researching this watch. ??

The reviews on the battery life made me iffy about buying it but I haven't had an issue with that. It's between 50-70% (depending on the watch face I use) by the time I get home (10?ish hour day). Took it off the charger at 6:30a today. It's 8:23p and has 33% charge. There's all these different battery settings you can use to extend the life. I had a Galaxy Active. I wanted my watch to make noise and Galaxy did not. The vibration isn't what I wanted either. I do a lot of moving at work and don't always hear/feel my phone. This watch is loud and clear. The vibration is very noticeable.

I guess since I have average size womens' wrists, maybe I should have gotten the Juliana? But that's not what I wanted ??????? Anyway, I made an extra hole. That was a little tough, too. ???? July 2021 Update: I haven't had ANY issues with my watch. I thought I may have an issue due to the physicality of my job, but nope! They've done an update on the WearOS app and I'm glad. It isn't 100% better, but it is 54.96% better than it was. ?? Everything is copastetic.

I've had this for a few weeks now, and I'll say that I'm overall happy with my purchase. For some background, I'm a Pixel owner who was looking for something that would feel seamless with the most recent Android operating system. I also wanted something that looked like a watch rather than a fitness band, as well as something that had GPS built in to track my bike rides.

Pros:
* Well-built physical quality - I've worn it every day since it came, and it has been both comfortable and resilient. Granted, I work from home currently, so we'll see how it hold up when I'm back to a daily commute to the office.
* Good variety of features - it has bluetooth, wifi, GPS, and NFC. It has lots of apps to add if you like, as well as lots of watch face options. For the price, it's got a robust feature set that you can tailor to whatever you need.
* Good Android integration - one of the main reasons I got it. It's been nice to have it automatically feed my step counts and GPS into other apps
* Google Pay and Google Assistant integration - Pay has been great, and I've started using it to pay whenever I end up buying something in person. I haven't really used assistant all that often, but largely because I have Google Home Minis throughout the house and I don't leave much. I'm hopeful that I can use assistant a bit more down the road
* Always on display - I like that it still feels like a watch. I can look at my wrist to see the time
* Swappable bands - I got a second band (leather) from Fossil, and it's easy to swap to fit my mood.

Cons:
* Terrible setup UX - took me forever. I had to restart and reinstall several apps in order to just get it to recognize my phone.
* Battery life - just isn't that great if you wear it all day with Bluetooth, Wifi, and notifications all day
* Battery saving modes - while I understand why it does it, I wish it wouldn't turn off bluetooth randomly to save battery. I suddenly realize I've missed messages because of the switch
* Weird connectivity overall - I've had a lot of dropped connectivity between this and my phone. I feel like it may have to do with connecting my phone to my computer, however, so I'm still troubleshooting
* Charger feels cheap
* I wish they sent something to remove links. I have very large hands/forearms, and it was big on me, so I'd imagine I'm not the only one in this boat. I ended up going ot the Fossil store, and they were incredibly nice and accommodating. They helped me get the fit just-right. Still, would be nice to have better instructions to do it myself

Overall, this felt like, and still feels like, the best option on the market for a Pixel owner. It does everything I needed it to do, despite some quirks. If they could bring in some minor improvements, I feel like it would knock it out of the park.
I bought it for a friend as a gift, and he loves it.

Overall, definitely a great buy from what I consider a great company, over the years I've had many different fossil watches. This smart watch has been great only downfall is the charger doesn’t always connect to your watch to charge. Since the watch was gifted to me I've purchased 2 more chargers since 2021 with other smart watch companies I didn't have to buy a new charger. Sometimes the sleep tracker is a bit off but other than that, it's great!

My husband’s first smart watch. Bought so i could text him at work and he could at lear see it but he can text back on the watch. So has a keyboard. He does get sms notifications and even pics when i send one.  He really loves it. Battery life has been good. He mostly wears it for work. After 8 hours at work with alot of movement he has about 75 percent left. He thought it was just another watch when he opened it. I had to tell him it was a smart watch. He loves the leather band as well. Fossil has been a great brand so far.

It has been almost two years since I started wearing this and I thought I would come back and give a last update. At this point I wear this some of the time. It went from the watch I used most to this. Main reason for this was the battery hassle. You have to turn the display off and can't even use shake to activate to get a full day of use out of it. And I can't really be bothered having to charge it every day. I've switched mostly to a Skagen hybrid smart watch. I can't make calls using it but I don't really need it for that anyway.
All that aside, I do still like this fossil watch. The functions are incredibly useful, there's lots of space left to get apps, and it has lost nothing of it's functions.

I started out rating this quite highly because my initial impression is that it is a great watch. This can change and I will come back to update this if it turns out to be poor.
Set up. Oh this was hard at first but deep breath, it can be done with minimal fuss and a time travel device. Dont pair your phone using Bluetooth until the prompt tells you to do it. Download wear os while this thing starts up. Allow locations in your phone settings then follow the wear os directions while your phone is next to the watch. It will set up but your phone has a Bluetooth pass code to connect. If it fails it's because your phone has already connected so you need to factory restore the watch and restart your phone.
Apps. Great connectivity from a Google phone as it lets you connect to all the apps from your account with minimal fuss. Download for Facebook messenger took a little while but nothing bad.
Battery seems to drop off very quick with extended use and download for apps. There is a battery customization mode to let you use it as little as possible to make the battery last. Also you can turn the display always on mode to off and save more power. Initially it was draining quickly so I will come back and let you know how it goes.
Appearance very nice but I'm afraid of that large display and have already bought screen protectors. Totally recommending this if you get this watch. The screen is huge and it is sensetive too. You can swipe easily and it doesn't appear to lag. This means it's expensive to replace so don't take a risk with it.

And I will be back to update.

Update... I'm discovering what some of the other reviewers said about the battery. On normal use mode it wouldn't last a day before you have to recharge it. So I'm taking it down to 4 stars because of that. This doesn't mean it's bad. It means you must go to the battery options and set it to extended use. I can tell you I left the house this morning at  7 am with the battery at 100%, returning home at 4.30pm and it's at 77%. This is with extended use settings and throughout the day very minimal use of the watch. Turning it on to check the time, pestering the wifey with a few nuisance texts, glancing at the news headlines because I was bored at work. That sort of thing.
For me this isn't perfect but it's not terrible either. I don't mind charging at the end of the day.
One other thing I noticed is that you must swipe from the sides. It might feel unresponsive to touch gestures but it really isn't. You just have to start at the side.

Also tried making a phone call with the watch. I had to footer about with the settings a bit to get it to work but once it was set up correctly, the call quality was fine. I could hear the other person well and the call on the other end was working great, too.
Also tried speech to text and as per usual for Scottish folk, that doesn't always work out too well. Can't blame the watch for that.

A sort of update to the update...

Ok I get it now. I had an initial impression followed by the first part of a learning curve. That's my mistake.  This is the first smart watch I have used and my reaction was to treat it like a normal watch but one that does stuff. It's not quite that. It's a device that comes with a learning curve. You have to be patient with it and learn how to use it, what to do, how to experiment with it, and what not to do. One week in and I'm finding that out for myself by downloading new apps, and discarding others, changing settings and learning new functions.. So far my Impression is net positive. I'm happy with this and look forward to using it going forward.

Update...

I dont really need to charge this every day but find myself doing so anyway. If you want to keep a decent charge of 80 percent or so then you need to charge each day. But that's not a hassle because it charges quickly.
 Loving some of the apps for this. Fotmob has all the soccer scores I want and it will ring on my watch to let me know when my team are tragically losing once again.
There appears to be a distance I can remain close to my phone to have all the functions work properly. I've noticed indoors it appears to be about fifteen feet or so. I'm happy with that. Still very happy with the watch.

Update. Last one I think. Changed it from a four to a three. I like it, but made a discovery that made me like it a little less. I took it off for the weekend, with the whole thing set to basically off. I didn't touch it and the watch wasn't doing anything for two whole days. When I took it off the charge was about 80 percent and when I picked it up again it was about 16 percent.
That's just daft. The battery ran down doing nothing.
Ugh.

I've been patiently waiting for years, for the perfect smart watch that would "check all the boxes," and the Fossil Gen 5 comes pretty close.  Here's my honest review.

THE FACE
When I opened the box, the watch face was smaller than I expected, and I was disappointed to see that a black circle of non-active margin surrounds that actual display, making the real display even smaller than the smaller-than-expected watch face. But I've survived a week with it. Also, I don't know that other watches out there have a larger display. This was just my reaction to it.

FONT SIZE
Next, I noticed just how small the type/font is on the screen for most notifications. Given my age and eye sight, the tiny print was near impossible to read. Fortunately, there is an accessibility setting to slightly increase the font size, though not much.

BUILD QUALITY
The watch itself is built well, and it seems solid. The stainless steel band seems light weight, but does a good job. As a whole, it does not feel like a toy. It feels like a mid-range watch.

CHARGING CORD
The charging cord, however, feels like a cheap piece of plastic and wire. It does not feel like a brand-name item, but rather, it feels like a replacement cord you would find on a rack for $1.

The charging wire does not come with a charging block. Instead, you have to plug the USB-A end of it into a computer or other USB outlet.

Also, the charging wire is incredibly short. Way too short. I don't think it's even 3 feet. It would be fine if it were plugged into my computer, but it's not at all long enough to have on your nightstand, even if an outlet us nearby on the wall.

Lastly, the charging cord is magnetic and snaps onto the back. Two small pins then make contact with the case to charge. (It is not wireless.) HOWEVER, it's a relatively loose fit and does not have that satisfying snap connection that you expect. So you connect it, and set your watch down and just HOPE that it stays connected. I would prefer a connection that snaps, has a strong magnet, and you can feel confident in the connection.

APPS
I am incredibly disappointed in the lack of apps for this smart watch, and for Wear OS in general. You would think that the company that makes Wear OS (Google) would make apps for it's most popular products like Gmail... but no, there is no Gmail app. There's no Google Voice app. etc.

NOTIFICATIONS
While there aren't many apps to use, the notifications do work well. When your phone would normally beep or vibrate, so too does your watch. It shows me notifications for incoming Email, Google Voice messages, and even notifications from other apps. That's nice. For the messages, you can often reply back to the person, by using either the microphone or smart reply. That's nice.

A big downside of the notifications system, however, is that there's no way to go back and look at previous or old notifications. So if grandma sent an email to me 20 minutes ago, and I already swiped away the notification, I cannot go back to it.

NFC
I waited for a watch that has NFC for mobile payments / Google Pay. This watch does it, but so far I have not used it. I have my credit card all set up, but the first time I was at a store, I could not get the watch to do it, and I had to resort to my phone. This may be user error on my part. Hopefully I can learn to just quickly use my watch.

GOOGLE FIT
For tracking fitness, I like that the watch is counting my steps, and that I can see my overall accomplishments for the day. I can use the watch to start a new activity (like running) but in that process, the crown does not function to scroll the list of activities. So you have to use your finger on the small screen.

PHONE CALLS
I also waited for a watch that has a speaker and mic. So far I have only accepted one call on my watch. I guess it was okay. Unfortunately people just don't make calls these days so it's not something I've used much.

SPEAKER / MUSIC / MEDIA
I have not been able to play music directly on the watch and out of the watch's speaker. I've also not played music from the watch and to headphones. So I cannot say those things work or don't. When you are using Spotify or Google Play, you can use the watch to skip forward and back on tracks, and play/pause, and adjust volume. I've used the watch to control music playing across the room on my Google Home; the stream was coming from the network and not from the watch.

FINAL RULING
This watch normally sells for $295 and I bought it on sale for $205. When I first opened the package and played with it for about 30 minutes, my gut told me to send it back. But I decided to give it some time and extra chances. During the past week I have learned to appreciate the heart rate monitor and step counting aspect of the watch. I suppose I could say I like the notifications, too, though I am not too sure how much that helps my life versus the identical notifications on my phone! I admit to being a Google Fanboy with the latest Google products, and at the same time I am incredibly jealous that it SEEMS those with Apple Watches can do far more with their watch/phone combo. I could be wrong, but I bet they have better access to their email, messages, etc, via their watches. Is the Fossil Gen 5 worth $205, probably. Would I recommend it for $295? No way. Do I hope a future Wear OS has better features that can compete with Apple, and would I pay extra for that? Absolutely.

As you can tell, this is a quick summary of my experience using this watch with an IPhone, but a lot of the issues would be present no matter what device you have. It should also be noted I have the iPhone XR, which still functions great but is a couple years old now.
To start off, it was a rocky setup. I downloaded the “wearOS” app and the google fit app like it requires, and got everything set up. It was very glitchy and many of the features flat out didn’t work and it couldn’t stay connected. But once I factory reset the watch and went over the setup again, it seemed to work much better.
It also seems to work better when you keep the “wearOS” app open on the background. That probably sounds like it should be obvious but since everything goes through Bluetooth I figured it’d be fine. I’m the type that never really keeps any app running in the background.
As far as features, it has everything you could want but you can’t use any of them due to the stupid low battery life. On an average day, it tracks my steps fine and I occasionally ask it for a BPM. This will being the battery down to about 15% by the time I’m going to bed. Although, if you do anything else such as use more apps or track a workout with it for longer then 30 minutes, it will die on you before the sun sets. It’s definitely not meant for longer durations of tracking, which also means sleep tracking is non existent unless you manage to charge it right before bed and then use the watch. But not only will you need to charge it again once awake, I doubt it will get through the full night before it’s dead again.
Answering phone calls on this thing and trying to use the microphone is a joke. Unless you’re in a quiet, private area, you won’t be able to hear the caller. And to them, you either sound far away, or underwater.
Lastly is the Bluetooth interruptions. I feel like this is one of the biggest problems for most people because more and more devices require Bluetooth pairing, like car radios for example. For whatever reason, this watch will override whatever other device you try to use. The only fix I have for it is to completely turn off the Bluetooth on my phone, then turn it back on and connect to the device before the watch connects. Even the phone calls, when I answer a call using my truck, it’ll sometimes switch to my watch for no reason after a few minutes.
All in all, it’s not really worth the price. It’s got tons of features and looks pretty slick, but the terrible battery life, dumb random glitches, and the way it wants to prioritize itself above everything is just not worth it. If you catch this on sale for less than $200 maybe give it a go. But I would honestly save up the extra hundred or two for something better. Especially if you’re an IPhone user.

It has been a few days and I truly love this watch. It's by far the most beautiful watch in it's class. It's first and foremost a smartwatch designed to look amazing, with fitness tracker features pumped into it. The mobile app is well put together with a lot of customizable options, but I wish it had a couple of features.

PROS
Beautiful watch.
Smooth and efficient touchscreen.
8G memory great for tons of apps.
Many customizable options.
GPS, NFC
Speaker is surprisingly loud.
The list goes on and on.

CONS
Battery life is poor given all the hi-tech stuff that demand juice. First couple of days I literally watched the battery drain in a few hours, but after a few days of tweaking features it started about a day. Time only mode makes it last longer but you'll have to restart the watch to get out of that mode. Maybe a free extra car charger would help in the meantime.
Silicon band isn't the best quality, started showing streaks by day 2...but it's very comfortable though.

WISH LIST
Battery last up to a week with GPS/NFC off.
Be able to store pics/audio/video through the app so they can be played or viewed later. The Fossil hybrid HR lets you load pic without FB.

UPDATE
After almost 2 months I still love the watch...except the really bad battery life. It has never lasted beyond 36hrs (1.5days) even tho i turn off everything (NFC, GPS, wifi, tilt to wake, touch to wake, always on, speaker etc).
Basically, with btooth off at night, and notifications turned off 6hrs a day, it might last 24hrs. You have to not use it in order to be able to use it...yea, might defeat the purpose.
It would've been perfect if it could last a few days. Might just switch to the not so beautiful Samsung galaxy 3.

I will not buy another Fossil. After only 1.5 years of owning this Fossil Gen 5 I'm about to buy a Samsung watch because I'm fed up with recent performance of the Fossil Gen 5. Once bitten...

Soon after the warranty expired I started having problems with battery life. The problems seemed to coincide with an update of the Fossil app, but I can't be certain of that. What I know is that certain battery mode options were removed. What's more, the update removed the OEM watch face I was using, and did not offer a new suitable similar watch face. In all fairness, a recent Fossil update restored the watch face that was removed.

Despite running the same apps and same settings daily, battery life has always been unpredictable, but it used to last a day. Not so much any more even under very restricted usage.

During the first year I was running with Gestures, WiFi, Bluetooth, heart-rate tracking, and NFC on, and without the always-on screen (instead a gesture would turn on the screen). Prior to the update the watch still had 30-50% of life remaining after a workday. Some days it would use battery at a faster rate than other days, and on the worst days it would automatically switch to extended mode in need of a charge. I would put it back on the charger before bed, then at bedtime use it overnight for sleep tracking. Overnight the battery drain was minimal.

Now days, after the Fossil update (and after warranty expiration), the battery will run dry in four hours or less using the same settings I was using in the first year. It won't even last for a full night's sleep. Occasionally it will last a workday, but that is rare and I have not been able to figure out why some days are good. I have since turned off gestures, WiFi, and NFC. With those "desired" features disabled I can usually get a full day out of the watch, but at the expense of not using features that I want.

And yes...I did do a factory reset hoping that would resolve the problems. No luck. The same issues were evident even before I started putting my few apps back on the watch.

Still, and here's that unpredictable part again, occasionally when I take the watch off the charger, with the features still turned off, the watch starts churning through the battery at an alarming rate. In minutes it will turn itself off and the only way to turn it back on is to put it on the charger again. After the watch restarts it will indicate the battery is quite high...like 85%. So why did it shut down?

In my opinion paying a premium price for just over one year of good use is not acceptable.  I'm hoping my next watch (from Samsung) will be a much better experience.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Original review: Nice looking watch, better battery life than expected.

I'm pleased so far with this purchase. I was concerned about the battery life I would get, but so far battery life has not been an issue. Keep in mind that the first day or so the watch will be installing updates and new apps, and you will spend more time with it. But with all of that done, I'm getting well over a full day. It will still have ~25% of battery remaining when I put it back on the charger. This is even after using it all night for sleep monitoring!

The only things I've turned off are the Always On display and the "OK Google" detection. For the display, I have activated gestures so that the display comes on when I rotate my wrist. As for OK Google, I just swipe left for the Google Assistant. I have not disabled heart rate tracking, and I let Google Fit monitor (heart/steps) all the time. Otherwise I'd forget to start it for a workout.

As for charging, the watch charges to 100% in about an hour. I think the only con I can come up with is that this watch does not work with wireless charging (as do some Galaxy watches). It would be nice to be able to use the wireless back-to-back charging capability from my phone if I'm ever caught out without the phone's own charger. Hopefully Fossil will offer that next time around.

As for being a watch, it works nice. It has apps for stopwatch and timers. I've not played much with the watch faces...I just picked one and probably will rarely change it. The watch works well with texting, email (including Outlook), calendar, and weather.

I cannot yet speak using the watch for phone calls. I have not yet had an opportunity for a Dick Tracey wrist phone experience.

I've recently installed the Sleep as Android app. So far it is impressive for what it is. I wear the watch overnight so I don't have to leave my phone on the bed. I have not yet tried the Cardiogram app.

Other apps I've loaded: A great compass app (Steel 3d I think?). Google Pay...works great on the watch! Google Maps is loaded, but I have not used it yet.

If you are into disc golf, you can keep score for multiple players on your watch using the UDisc app. I've done so several times and it has mostly worked great. Twice though it had a syncing issue where I had to finish keeping score on my phone. Both times I had opened the phone to access other features of UDisc, after which the watch scoring glitched. I think that's just a syncing bug that UDisc needs to figure out.

As for size, I was concerned about that too. I do not like the oversized mongo watches. I prefer something less bulky. This is as large as I would want on my average sized wrists. Anything larger would be too big, I think. Anything smaller would not be usable for a smart watch.

I bought the version with the brown leather band. The leather band is very nice...good quality. I also bought an after-market silicone band for playtime. I'd rather preserve the nice leather band for dressier occasions.

I avoided buying a smart watch for years because I was not impressed by the battery life and the apps available. I am happy to say that I think they are worth it now. My only fear now is that Google will abandon Wear OS following the Fitbit acquisition. I hope not, because I think Wear OS is just now coming into it's own and can only get better as more developers and manufacturers adopt it.

Fossil is well knows brand of watches. I was looking for a Wearos based Smart watch for  last few months. I got opportunities to try other competing brands of smartwatches of the same price range. Fossil Gen 5 meet my expectations and I would recommend this watch because of the following pros:-
1. Size: the round watch fits perfectly on your wrists and give an executive look. You never feel the watch is heavy for your wrist.
2. Display: Scratch free and waterproof display works perfectly together with soft touch screen.
3. Buttons: Easy scrolling and fast responses middle button. The two up and down small buttons can be customised.
4. Interface: Initial configuration is very simple and easy.  WearOS allows you to connect with your smartphone quickly, easily. The connection seems to be very stable.
5. Install/Uninstall custom applications: Most of the necessary applications that you use in smartphone are available in WearOS. Google Play Store is pre-installed.
6. Activity tracking: Google for works perfect and synch with the phone.
7. Notification: Keep your phone away and see all the notifications in your writst. Reply to email/messages/WhatsApp/Mail/Facebook, etc..
6. Speaker & Microphone: in-built speaker and Microphone allow you to make/answer calls and get quick audible ouput from Google Assistant. Use Google Assistant as you use in your phone.
7. Memory: The watch has 1Gb RAM and approximately 5.6Gb internal memory got storage. The watch is relatively Faster compared to the other competing brands.
8. Battery modes: it has Daily/Extend/Custom/ Time-only modes. On average 1.5 days with all Daily mode. Time custom mode or Time only mode to save battery if needed.
9. Charger: Very light weight and not bulky charger. Comfortable to use.
10. Band - I used the Silicon band and I love it. It is water proof.

Most commonly reportedly issues and tips.

1. Google Assistant audio response not working -- It works if you set the same language (eg. English U.S) in your phone and watch.
2. Unable to use watch mic and speaker to answer call -- For this you have to make sure that  I). 'Use phone audio in watch' is ON in watch, ii) While pairing with your blue tooth turn on the option for pairing audio in phone (go to blue tooth settings on your phone and click on the watch name, change settings).
3. Battery life: the watch holds many functions as a  mini wrist phone. To extend the battery life please use a suitable battey mode, turn off WiFi and locations if not necessary. Use 'low energy source' charger like USB port of your laptop.

I hope you enjoy the watch.
Cons: I dont think is there something to highlight.

Some people say the battery performance is poor, but it depends on their use and battey mode.

** It is an Unbiased review based on my experience and experience from my close friends.

Thank you

I've had this for just under a week now and so far I really like it. My only legit complaint is the knobs and buttons on the side of the watch frame. I wish they were flat, I find that I accidentally long press the google assistant button a lot when I have to bend my wrist for more than a second. This hasn't been enough for me to return the watch though. I've just ended up pushing it up on my wrist a little higher and it seems to have helped. Additionally, the wrist straps are incredibly easy to swap. There's just a little silver nub where the band connects to the watch on the underside, you have to slide and hold it and the band comes out. Makes for incredibly easy changing between sport bands and nicer leather or metal bands for more formal situations. I took them both off and put them back on in less than a minute.

Now for the big stuff -- I'll get right to it first and foremost since it is mentioned in a lot of reviews. The battery...

**For anyone claiming to have terrible battery right out of the box, I suggest installing all the updates and doing a full overnight charge first. Battery performance was a little wonky during setup and while downloading and installing the updates, but after the first night it's been great. If you still have trouble then I suggest returning it or contacting Fossil for support for defective battery. ***

BATTERY LIFE - I've customized some of the features, but for the most part they're all on. I've only turned off the sound and the ability to answer and take calls on the watch. I've never had to do take a call on my watch and I just see it as an irrelevant feature personally.  Additionally, I don't have the screen set to "always on" or "touch to wake" and instead use "tilt to wake". I start my day at 6:30a with 100% watch battery and arrive home about 5p every day and haven't fallen below 60% battery. This is with the features below on and with normal use by replying to texts, tracking walks with GPS, setting timers and alerts and occasionally using the google assistant.

I have the following all turned on 100% of the time:
-GPS (only activates while tracking exercise)
-Wifi - always on and connected to my phone when not in bluetooth range
-Cloud backup
-Heart rate  monitoring (set to measure HR every 10 minutes all day)
-Google Fit Syncing

Water resistance - According to the Fossil website, this watch is 3 ATM rated water resistance which means you can shower, wash your hands, get sweaty, etc without worrying. The 3 ATM rating means you should (in theory) be able to submerge your watch in water while swimming up to a depth of 100 feet. I personally don't know if I want to test this, but I have gotten it wet while washing my hands and its been fine.

It's got a little bit of weight to it, so coming from a samsung gearfit that was rectangle and very light, it's taken some getting used to with the weight and round shape. It is a solid watch though.

The screen is excellent, I've used it in a variety of lighting, including high-noon direct sunlight and the screen brightens up and it's perfectly readable. If you have bigger fingers, some of the buttons can be a little annoying to tap, but overall I've not had any major issue with the touch screen.

The silicon strap is comfortable and has many notches for the perfect fit. As I said above, also incredibly easy to swap between the sport bands and a nicer leather or metal band.

In conclusion, I was worried a little bit about getting a round watch and I had been keeping my eye out for a square option, but I haven't found any with Wear OS support (this was important to me for fitness tracking with google Fit). I'm glad I went with this option though because the watch looks great and I can get a nicer band to wear to more formal functions.

This is my second smartwatch. My first smart watch was a Huawei First Generation. I was very resistant at first getting a smart watch because I hate the square bezel look ( Apple). My Huawei still works but after about four years of ownership the LCD screen has been developing some "artifacts" ( LCD burn in, like the old plasma TVs).
I've been watching some smart watches for about 1 year now and had price alerts on them. The Fossil went considerably lower, to a price that I was comfortable with ( well under $200 ). I had to buy it. I had my eye on some Samsung Galaxy which I heard has amazing battery life but since my old watch was using Wear OS Google, I didn't feel like jumping ship to Tizen.
So, the good about the watch...it is a very good looking watch. I have the metal bracelet smoke. I like the fact that the screen on the outside is just as big as my Huawei (44mm I think) which isn't big. I have a medium size wrist. It is thinner and much lighter than Huawei 1st generation. The quality of the graphics is top notch. Set up was easy, painless on my Motorola Z4 phone. It stays connected, never drops off bluetooth. I didn't buy it to use the workout functions. They could be great, I don't know but if I wanted a workout watch I would buy an ugly square Garmin or whatever. I like to get texts, answer calls on it, do some speech to text replies. It works great for that. The screen brightness I think it is great. I keep it on auto or brightness at level 2.
So, now the bad. Biggest elephant in the room is the battery life. I kept it on the daily battery function with brightness on auto and most of the sensors off, but wifi and bluetooth on. I also keep the screen always on, but obviously it darkness a little after 3-5 seconds. I don't want that function off. I need to be able to see what time it is at a quick glance without needing to touch the screen, buttons, etc. I do get notifications but only messages ( WhatsApp, Viber and Messages). I don't really talk on it. I get about 15-25 WhatsApp messages per day, 20-25 texts and 3-4 Viber texts. I never check heart rate, never use GPS, NFC ( those are off). So my first day with it, the battery lasted 12 hours. My 4 year old Huawei lasts the same.??
I know the battery is only slightly bigger in Fossil than the Huawei but c'mon...I was expecting close to 24 hrs.
Also, the graphics of watch faces don't seem to cover the whole glass area. There's a tiny portion that isn't covered. Not a big deal but my Huawei is pretty much full screen. So I don't want to say Fossil is a bad watch. Not at all, but let me summarize. If I had paid $295 ( full price) for my Huawei 1st generation, I would  still be very pleased. If I would have paid $280 for the Fossil...hmm....??....not really. Battery let's it down. At the price I paid? I am not dancing with joy but I think is ok. I am torn between three and four stars but battery life is a big deal to me and because of this, I have a hard time giving it a four.
So, after a few days of playing with the setting I think I can get 16-18 hrs of battery which I guess it's ok. I turn Wifi Off, NFC off, heart monitoring off and I keep the brightness at 2 which for me is plenty. The watch is otherwise flawless. I decided to give it a four star.

I didn't really see a reason to own a wearable, but I was intrigued and I figured I'd see what all the fuss was about.  I wanted something that would sync up effortlessly with my Pixel 3, be highly readable, offer vibe, and have physical buttons.  I also wanted a round face (I find the square/rectangular ones ugly) and a metal band.  That narrowed the field down considerably.  The Galaxy Watch was a strong contender until I realized that many of the features are only active with Galaxy phones.  A buddy at work has a Garmin Fenix for twice the price of the Fossil.  I ordered the Fossil.

Setup went easy and I had it running/synced in minutes.  The smoked stainless looks very classy, much better than the cheap, plasticky look of many of these devices.  There was plenty room in the bracelet even with my thick wrist - I ended up pulling two links (doable, but not very easy).

I was initially disappointed with the size of the digital display font despite the large face, and none of the options on the WearOS app seemed to be "just right".  In addition, the battery life was not great for the first couple of days.  It took me some doing, but I found a free face on a third party app that looks and works terrific, plus it seems to have extended the battery life.  I can go 18+ hours on a full charge with the ambient display and BT on, however the charger works very quickly - popping on the charger for even a few minutes can add several hours.

It's grown on me over the past few weeks and I am finding it very convenient to simply glance at it to see if the email/text is worth immediate attention.  Sending quick SMS/email replies is simple, either with the suggestions or (amazingly) the tiny keyboard.  Also, I get an SMS for dual layer authentication at work,12+ times a day, so that alone makes it very useful.  The speakerphone is OK only if you have HD voice.  I've toyed with some of the apps like Fit and Cardiogram.  They seem to do what they're supposed to do, but I was really in for the productivity. About the only complaint I have is the size of the crown/main button.  It's quite large and easy to press, so it's easy to accidentally depress any time I bend my wrist back, though wearing it a little higher on the wrist has helped.

I'll edit if anything notable pops up, but for now I'll say that this was a very good choice at the price point.

I've been a wear OS (Android Wear) person pretty much since the first few watches came out.  I first got the Moto 360 and then the Huawei Watch and then the Huawei Watch 2.  In each instance, I've been fairly happy with the devices and the quality of the devices themselves.  Wear OS's problems are something else.  That's Google for you but given that I'm not a Samsung or Apple fan, I've done what I can to steer clear of those brands.

My last Wear OS watch was the Huawei Watch 2 and I got a full 2 years of use out of that one.  Towards the end, it started to act up but that coincided with the release of the Gen 5 and the subsequent sale on Black Friday.  I was waiting for that to happen, hoping to eek out a few more days and weeks from my Huawei watch.

So far, I've only had my Gen 5 for a couple of days.  It's hard to say how the battery life is after just those 2 days but I can say this.  The watch charges fast.  Real fast.  I was at 58% yesterday and I set it on the charger before I went to wash up for bed.  By the time I got back to the watch, it was fully charged.  That was maybe 30 minutes.  So I took the watch off the charger and I set it aside to see what the battery power would look like in the morning.  Not too shabby...it was at 91% this morning when I put it on.

The Huawei watch had 768MB of ram (IF memory serves correctly) but even with that, Wear OS was still sort of slow and glitchy.  The 1GB on the Gen 5 definitely makes a difference.  It still has moments when it glitches and slows a little but it's a lot better.  I don't have nearly as many moments.  The watch is much more responsive and I think I will enjoy getting Google Pay back.  For the most part, I would have to say the Gen 5 is very smooth and responsive.  Coming from those other watches, I have nothing to complain about.

Just a comparison...I also recently bought my wife a Samsung Galaxy watch.  Yes, I went to Samsung for her but she also owns a Samsung phone and doesn't have the same feelings about Samsung as I.  She started using it on Friday and even though she is happy with it overall, her battery isn't doing any better than my Gen 5.  She did get the smaller 42mm version with the smaller battery but I've seen numerous reviews about it saying that they get about 2&1/2 days to even 3 days out of a charge.  The wife might swing 1&1/2 days which is on par with what I'm seeing with the Gen 5.  But I can say one thing...helping her setup of the Tizen OS based watch made me want to stick with my familiar Wear OS watch even more.  You can't undo 4+ years of familiarity with a particular brand.

About the Gen 5, I really like the big main button with the spinning dial.  The galaxy watch has the spinning bezel.  This has the spinning dial and I think I like that more than the spinning bezel.  Google assistant pulls up fast and it listens pretty well.  I was having some issues having it text my wife but that's something I'll check on further.  But at least between my phone and my watch, if I need to rattle off a quick message to someone while driving, I can voice activate things and speak my message and get it done that way without taking my attention off the road.

So far, this watch has been everything that I wanted and hoped for.  I haven't tested the watch in water yet and I might not do that anytime too soon as I don't hit the water too often.  But I'm sure it's better than my Huawei watch and I took that into the pool a few times.

From having my eye on this watch since it was announced to seeing it in store at a Fossil in Vegas and to finally getting it on my wrist, I can honestly say that this is the best Wear OS has to offer.  Fossil makes most of the watches with wear os.  The Emporio Armani Smartwatch 3 is a nice looking watch and it was just announced but I don't think it's worth the extra money.  The Gen 5 I think looks like a very nice watch.  It can work in any situation.  Much more versatile than my Huawei watch 2.

Update:  I can definitely confirm that I love my gen 5. I've had it for a couple of weeks now. It feels so familiar to me but it runs so much smoother than all the previous watches. The battery life gets me a full day without any trouble. I'm using a watch face off the play store that gives me options to show on the screen. But even with this face and constant notifications all day, I'm somewhere between 45-60% after 16 hours. I could probably eek out 2 days in some situations but I'm an overnight charging person anyways so why bother trying for it... This is the best of wear os until the new chip gets released and maybe, something from Google gets released now that they own fitbit.
