Be sure to buy one that has the U.S. warranty in case you have a problem.

For a refurbished item it's a worthwhile  expenses. Watchband is a little on the cheapish side,but  seems to be holding up o.k.
Power button is a little finicky but usable.

The rotating bezel is a joy to use on this watch. The implementation feels natural, and I wish all smart watches would use something similar. The clicks feel satisfying, and TizenOS takes advantage of the bezel too.

The size is great, and 42mm fits my wrist perfectly. Although it still is a thick watch, every smart watch is going to be relatively thick compared to normal watches as well. I think you'd have to have a very large wrist to warrant the 46mm (or you might want the bigger screen/battery).

I don't find the shortage of third-party apps in TizenOS to be restrictive. I mostly use the watch to track my runs, and view notifications without needing to access my phone. I can't imagine what else I would need.

The battery life is okay. I get about 1 full day with my current setup: brightness at 2, always on display, location off, heart-rate every 10 minutes. I put the watch on before bed, then charge it the evening of the next day (~16-20 hours of use).

I think this is currently the best smart watch out there for Android phones. Even better if you have a Samsung phone. It's almost a no-brainer if you have a Samsung phone already. I would highly recommend this watch!

If you're looking for an overpriced piece of of junk that tells you the time and counts your steps, then this is the watch for you! Other highlights...frequently looses connection with my phone despite being 10ft away. Randomly answers phone calls simultaneously along with my phone causing a confusing echo resulting in the other person hanging up. Sometimes notifies me of texts....sometimes doesn't. Basically it worked well for a short time and now it's basically a watch that counts steps and needs to be rebooted more and more frequently as time goes on. Oh...and Bluetooth is sometimes on and sometimes it discretely turns off on its own and you don't realize it for a day or 2 while you're wondering why this $200 weight on your wrist doesn't seem to be doing anything that is supposed to beyond telling time. Only had this for like 6 months and after the first 3 months or so, it became an unreliable piece of junk.

I came from a galaxy gear s2, unfortunately i lost the watch one day and decided to get this new version. This watch is what the s2 is but better, faster, and actually more usefull because of the gps and the speaker on it. What i loved about the s2 is that it was handy; i used the timer, the alarm, the heart rate monitor, back/next for music, basically little things/apps that were right there conveniently on my wrist. Now on this new version The gps on it can track my location and the speaker can announce information during my runs; handy stuff. Even though the apps on the appstore are 90% useless, the ones that are useful are AMAZING. To me a smartwatch is 1st a watch and second a piece of gear that SUPPLEMENTS your phone. I dont need to play games on my watch, look at pictures, watch youtube, and surf the internet from my watch; to me thats stupid. What i do need are little apps that help me get through the day rather than pulling out my phone which would actually be more time consuming; this watch is GREAT at doing that. If you want a handy piece of gear that can supplement your phone, this watch is awesome

The Watch is incredibly well built. The bezel is really awesome and the system is way ahead of Wear OS.
But the battery life is not that great.

I use the watch normally, with Always On (because it's a watch, its only natural that it always shows the time) but with WiFi off, NFC off, a lot of automatic sensors turned off and still it lasts only for a day... actually, less than that. I start using it at 7:30 and when its 23:00 the battery is already at less than 15%.

Also, the music controller on the exercise screen of the Samsung Health app doesn't work (but its a software bug, easy to repair). The Spotify app (in Remote mode, using connected to smartphone) is not working at the moment of this review too (but its also just a software issue).

Oooh, and don't expect to have a lot of beautiful watch faces on your watch unless you're willing to pay for them. The great majority of the faces that are actually cool or pretty are paid. Still, there's a lot of free ones too, but in a general way, they aren't that good.

Apart from those issues, the Watch is what I expected: a great amount of quality in one product.
Me agrado que se ve muy bien. La correa un poco pequeña. La carga dura menos de lo indicado pero nada grave. Esta funcional y buen precio

Ok first of all I have used several kinds of Fitbit’s and I can say I’d order this watch over and over again compared to any of them!! I absolutely love this watch, and love all the free faces, plus the ease of setting this up. I couldn’t ask for more out of a smartwatch, and you can download all kinds of apps and goodies for it, so don’t let the negative reviews get to your head, they are nit-picking at anything to complain about. Like I said, I’d definitely buy it again, and would recommend to anyone on the market for a true smartwatch that works flawlessly and runs quickly!!! And you CAN easily use WiFi and Bluetooth at the same time lol u have to use WiFi always on mode and then after setting it up you can switch back to auto mode..Wake up mode (when you move your wrist) CAN be adjusted where it is hard to get it to work, and it works flawlessly on mine,it also DOES give accurate heart rates, I own a couple different Fitbit that don’t have any more accurate than this, and my Bluetooth never randomly quits, sounds like people are trying to blame all their other problems on this watch and not the other stuff they have come to rely on (aka Fitbit) loI I love the crybabies that cant work technology and are making complaints and giving negative reviews..
Maybe before writing a negative review you should look up how to do it or something... or maybe if you can’t work technology, don’t blame the watch because you can’t figure out certain features and therefore give it a bad review (aka fake review) because you can’t work your technology or read directions!!!!

My Versa's battery stopped holding a charge after two years, and after reading reviews I learned that is a thing with those watches, so even though I was very happy with that watch I decided to try something different. My wife has a Galaxy Active, which led me to this watch.  After a couple of weeks, I like the Galaxy Watch. It's bulkier than the Versa, the battery takes longer to charge and doesn't last as long (this latter has been a disappointment after reading the reviews), but the big screen is easier to read and I think I will like the rotating bezel, which, if nothing else, acts as a bit of a protection for the screen ... and that's a good thing because given its larger size I have been bumping it into everything (and to think I was contemplating the 46mm!)  It has been staying reliably connected to my phone (S8), which is good because notifications is one of the primary reasons I wear a watch these days. All in all, I'm pleased ... I'll keep tweaking settings trying to get to 4 days of battery life, and I'm hoping that my Galaxy Watch lasts longer than 2 years!

I bought this to replace my GearFit2 Pro. I'm very surprised at how much I love it. I've always been the type of person that was like "I can just take my phone out of my pocket and read a notification, or see who is calling." Well that mindset changed a lot for me when I got the GearFit2 Pro to replace a Sony SmartBand I had.

Now that I have the Galaxy Watch I'm even more of a fan of having the notifications on my wrist. I can even take a call from my wrist instead of having to pull my phone out. It honestly makes life a little easier.

The battery life on mine is pretty good considering I have heart rate and stress monitoring on continuously. It last me about 2 full days.

I have a screen protector on my and I still haven't had to replace that. It doesn't seem to get beat up as much as you would think it would on your wrist.

I haven't had any issues with the buttons or the rotating bezel. I shower with it daily (unless it's on the charger). I haven't had any issues with it getting laggy or any other common issues I've heard about.

The step tracking seems to be on par with any other tracker I've used. The floor tracking however is far from perfect. I usually don't trust it by any means.

I replaced my stock band with a different band. It was easy and quick.

Overall I would recommend this smart watch. I'm even of thinking about buying a second for my fiance.

For a smaller guy as myself (5'9") I find the 42mm a great fit. The wake up gesture works great and I find the activity tracking works very well. I am not sleep expert, but the watch does seem to know exactly when I go to sleep and wake up. Not sure if I will even care in the coming weeks. but pretty neat at the moment.

However, I have a few minor issues I don't like and perhaps I will overcome them as I get more familiar with the watch.

Text messages
I have a Samsung Galaxy S8 and if I read my text messages on my watch, my phone does not mark the message as ready. I am using Google messages, so maybe its not compatible. But in my 2015 car I can read the message on the infotainment center and it gets acknowledged. Its not too big of a deal, but in my opinion, it kinda of defeats the purpose of using your watch.

Notifications
I have disabled most of the notifications I don't want to see. But I have not figured out how to disable the daily briefings, or when my phone is out of range (it vibrates) or some various other apps on the phone.

Goodnight mode
I love the goodnight mode feature. It seems to recognize when its getting close to bedtime, giving you the option to enable or suspend. But it does not always recognize when I get up. I find half the time I have to turn it off.

Battery life
I know the 42 has the smaller battery, but I am a little disappointed with the life so far. I have gotten close to two days of use before needing to recharge. My expectation was 3 full days. Of course I find myself messing with it often. Hopefully, the life will improve as I scale back my usage.

This watch is amazing, I have never had a watch before so this is my first but you can do so much with it. Measure your stress levels quite accurately, be able to see how long/well you sleep, calories, steps, and lots lots more in regards to health/calories/fitness. I was pleasantly surprised by the ease of navigating throughout the watch and it is quite nice to have it connected with my phone so when I get a text it pops up on my watch and I can quickly see who sent what and reply if needed. There are SO many faces available that you can choose from, I saw one from Fallout and it looked pretty awesome so I used that but there are literally hundreds of them. In terms of battery life it is not that great around two days maximum, but that's not necessarily bad unless you are constantly using your watch for fitness which tends to drain the battery quite fast. On an average of use it has gone from 100 to 70% with me, so technically speaking if you don't plan on using this so much for fitness tracking it can last up to 3 days without charging. The Samsung Pay feature is great as well I have both of my cards on there and if I need to pay I just put my wrist next to the credit card scanner machine and press pay. You can also download/play music on it or control the music on your phone, useful is you have headphones on and don't want to take your phone out and just scroll through quickly on your watch to the wanted song. All in all, definitely worth it this watch is awesome.

So I liked almost everything about this watch and it amazed me in many different ways like the customization and how high tech it is. you can do nearly everything you can on your phone on this watch except the obvious stuff like watch movies. I absolutely loved how it looks and it feels very solid, definitely very high quality. the clicking of the rotating navigation piece is super satisfying too. Overall its been a wonderful experience except 1 small thing... It is heavy! I know that sounds weird because it is just a watch how heavy can it be?, right? well it felt like i had a small weight strapped to my wrist all day and it actually began to hurt wearing it all the time. Now I'm sure i could continue wearing it an my muscles will adapt but honestly I'd rather wait for a lighter version in the future. So that being said if you are used to having something on your wrist all the time I definitely highly recommend this watch especially if you have a Samsung Galaxy phone. the battery was impressive for how much is going on in this little thing. it would last about 2 days and comes with a wireless charger that will get you 100% in about an hour. Also i have to mention the packaging for this was very nice, it was nice and compact and everything in the box was nice and tight. they definitely made sure these watches are getting to their new owners without problems, that's always nice to see.  great watch just not for me.

This watch growth on me. First day I wanted to give it 3 stars, second day I started to kind of like it, and from third day I am mostly loving it.

Pros:
* First non-Apple non-gigantic smartwatch that fits OK on my somewhat small wrist.
* Easy to disable all unnecessary notifications and make the watch unintrusive
* User interface seems very optimized. You don't need to do many clicks to get where you need. For me 95% of my needs are met on two screens - the watch face and swipe to the right for weather. That's it.
* Love the choice of watch faces and that you can fit time, fitness and weather (with some limitations) on one screen
* Fitness functions seem to work fine. Nice to be able to see your your speed and route on the map when you bike.

Neutral
* Battery lasts reliably two days. It can probably do 2.5 days total. Kind of same as the 1st gen Apple watch I had some years back.

Cons / to improve:
* Making it thinner would be nice. It is still a brick on your hand. Although for the fairness Samsung made it fairly elegant, but didn't do as good of a job of hiding thickness as apple did.
* Custom watch faces do not seem to include weather. I suspect some API limitations making weather unavailable to 3rd party developers.
* I wish some watch faces included not just current temperature, but also high and low for the day.
* Bixby speaks in a ridiculous computer voice, which no longer feels normal in the age of Alexa, Siri and Google Assistant, but is otherwise functional (e.g. I found it to be the simplest way to start timer when I do meditation).

I hope many further improvements will come via software updates.

I do love my watch.
Like I do every day, I took it off to charge it over night
Next morning when I took it off the charger I noticed the screen is broken (see picture).
Thought it was weird,how can I just break like that,but I figured just a malfunction screen,it happens.
So I went online @ Samsung.com since I registered it 6 month ago after I recieved it.
Good news!! Its under warranty(what I assumed since it literally just went bad over night)Yay!!
Filled out the online form included the picture.
24h later a customer representative called me,gave me via email the shipping instructions.
Shipped it off. Everything went smoothly, even customer service was great.
A week later I get a email saying I need to pay approximately 150$??.
I called them right away,asking why do I need to pay if it's under warranty.
She said because of water damage/ abuse it doesn't fall under warranty.
Water damage??? This watch is supposed to be waterproof!!! Even tho it didn't got in contact with water(I always took it off for showers and such).
So I argued with her for a minute about it and after I noticed I wouldn't win this battle I gave in and paid since it's just a fraction of the cost of a new one.
I'm just very upset that they claim it was "water damage/ abuse",pretty much my fault... what was not....I just charged it.
I personally think it's a way for them to get away not to pay for it.
I talked to a couple friends about that issue, they own a apple watch....2 of them had similar issues and apple did the same to them.
Its frustrating because I love my watch.
You can clearly see in the picture that the screen has no crack ,that this was a faulty screen.
Samsung you need to do a better job,take care of your customers!!
Had to sent the first watch back due to it being locked. They were understanding & offered to replace it. Sent it back & recieve my replacement today. Works great. Thanks

I bought my first Android smartphone in 2009, the MyTouch 3G.  It was the second android to hit the main market.  It never should have.

The technology was too immature.  It lacked the power to run all of the functionality it was supposed to have.  Often, when I would receive a phone call, the phone was SO laggy that the call would go to voicemail before the phone could let me answer it.  It was... gimmicky.  A smartphone, yes, but not really all that smart.

I feel similarly about the Galaxy Watch.  What does it really do besides be a smartwatch, by definition?  There were a few apps that were useful.  "Find my phone" was nice.  The apps for weather and such were also useful, but really not any easier than pulling out my phone.  I could send quick text responses, which was an upgrade over my previous wearable, a Fitbit Charge 2.

It was slow.  It would lag when it was doing nothing, processing nothing.  I would pull down the menu to put it into sleep mode, and it would lag when I did that, and when I pressed the button for sleep mode.  Why was it lagging?  It wasn't doing anything!  It wasn't sending or receiving data.  It wasn't even opening an app.  It lagged because it was evidently underpowered for even the performance of its most basic task, showing a watch face.

Battery life:  less than advertised.  If I let it run down to zero, it might last a day, a day and a few hours tops.  As it was, I would go to bed with it fully charged and it would easily run down to 78% overnight, on sleep mode.  And folks, let me tell you, I don't sleep long nights.  This, by the way, was with the setting on infrequent heart rate monitoring.  Speaking of heart rate monitoring, let's move on to my main reason for wanting a smart wearable, activity tracking.

It was ok at this.  It would count steps fine, and would automatically detect when I was on a walk or doing something else it considered exercise for ten minutes or more.  The display of fitness data was pretty.

It is garbage at tracking floors climbed.  I was lucky if it detected 1/4 of the floors climbed on any given day.  Samsung has been made aware of this, and thus far has basically shrugged its shoulders about it.  Sleep tracking was subpar.  Several nights, it failed to track sleep at all, and when it does track sleep, the data is very basic.

In the end, it's less functional at the things I prioritize and basically is only good at looking pretty and being high maintenance.  That's right, the Galaxy watch was effectively like a bad girlfriend or boyfriend*.

Anyway, I dumped it and instead bought the newer generation of my old fitbit, the Charge 3.  I now enjoy much better fitness tracking, dramatically superior battery life, and hey, the new fitbit can even send quick text responses, so now that's covered.  It was $130 cheaper and all I've really sacrificed is style points.

The lithium batteries at that time were not as good yet as they are today. A few months ago this watch started to keep the charge for shorter time. Few days ago it overheated at first and then completely died. It happened the same way years earlier than with the watch, when my Samsung smartphone not just overheated, but bloated when driving in the car and it was even dangerous. This watch just overheated and died. I do not recommend you to buy a used one.

I'm coming from OG Microsoft Band land, so have little to compare this to, honestly.

Don't try to install Spotify. It will drain your battery within hours because it constantly runs in the background without even using it. Hang up a call? Auto play Spotify. Mess with anything audio? Opens Spotify! I was stoked about this feature, but Samsung/Spotify really need to step up their game.

There's a little lag between receiving texts/calls and having the content show up on your watch, but overall this feature is about as good as I expected. Making and taking calls from my wrist is fantastic. Facebook messenger notifications do not show up.

Battery life, after uninstalling Spotify and resetting the watch is actually darn good. I can run a third party sleep tracker all night, track my training for several hours, and it's only at about 60% thereafter.

It sits a little funny on my tiny wrists. (5'4, 108lbs). I've tried right side up and upside down, but it's just weird- maybe that's me, though. A lot of times, turning my wrist to activate the watch face doesn't work... a lot of times it'll do it when I don't want it to. Little frustrating. Best bet is to forget set it to "always on" and very dim, or "always off", and press the home button to see it.

Heart rate tracker seems to be fairly accurate, but the watch is always telling me to slide it further up my arm. If I put it any further up, it'd be at my elbow. I'm an acrobat and have decent sized forearm muscles, so keeping it in place is difficult and a little inhibiting. I've tried flipping it upside down, no dice. Sometimes it just drops your HR and fills in the blanks with guesses.

GPS is hit or miss, but I'm in a rural area so take that with a grain of salt.

I'd say if you're looking for a decent balance between smart/fitness, this is about what you can expect. Smart watches and fitness trackers alike still leave a bit to be desired in 2018, and it seems no one watch has it all down pat.

*****ONE MONTH UPDATE*****
It's been a month now of daily use for sleep taking, weightlifting, running, yoga, and acrobatics practice.

I've taken away two stars because the heartrate tracker is just awful and unreliable. I don't know if it's because of my forearm anatomy that I mentioned in my initial review or because Samsung just really needs to up their game. My skin in basically translucent, and I adjust the watch whenever it says I need to scoot it up my arm a bit further, yet still it simply is not capable of tracking my heartrate when I am in or above my target/vigorous/max zone.

I've provided a picture of my data from yesterday's 5.5 mile trail run where you can clearly see that as soon as my HR was where I wanted it to be, the watch dropped it and lost it completely for nearly three entire remainder of my run. This means that the calories burned is inaccurate, and I don't have good info to go on to plan my next run. I came home with an exertion migraine, and although I'm not blaming that on the watch, it would have been nice to know that I was overdoing it a bit.

This is REALLY frustrating, and I'm considering returning the watch at this point.

I still have issues with the face waking up when I look at it, too, and don't want to set it to "always on".

I love the notification and calling features on this watch.  I dont have to pull out my phone to answer a text or to make a call i can see and answer them from my watch.  I can also make calls from the watch.  I have only used the watch for running so far and the metrics look good and I can control the music from my watch.

The 42mm watch is large for my very tiny wrists but still comfortable.  I really like the rotating bezel to find apps etc.  My garmin 735xt was out for repair so i ordered this for the calling features but my first impression is that garmin is still better for tracking sports.  Also I like to do sprint tris and the samsung galaxy wont track a tri.  I also love that my 735xt battery lasts for 7 days or so.  The galaxy seems like I will need to charge it every night.  Its a much more attractive watch than the 735xt and i like the barometer and altimeter.

I was considering the fenix 5s plus because it has maps and music but it is very pricey.  This watch has maps, but they come loaded with only a Korean gps location and so far I cant get it to load my location.  I was hoping to use this feature while biking and running but Im not sure this is possible.

I swapped the band already because I really didnt like the one it came with.

This watch comes in a 4g lte version.  I considered this so I could run without my phone, but decided against it since you need to pay another fee to your cellular provider to use it without your phone to make and receive calls.  I havent tried loading music on the phone yet but have used the watch to forward and pause tracks while running with i heart radio.

I also loaded the navigation app that goes with Google maps.  That works so when you set a use google maps on your phone your watch navigates your route

Update:. 9/12/18

One of the main reasons i decided on this watch is because I could answer calls on it while working without pulling out my phone.  This worked great until the last update, now my watch only buzzes and doesnt tell me who is calling and gives no options for answering.  Also I tried to use the find my car app and it doesnt seem to work.  The touch screen is lagging sometimes.  Also while working out it doesnt seem to read my hear rate.  Also I tried to reset the watch and I cant even do that.  I am seriously considering returning it even though I loved it for the first 2 weeks.
My husband loves it works great

It's a decent smart watch, but the only way you're going to get anywhere close to the advertised battery life is if you put a dark face on it, turn off always on display, and basically turn off all fitness tracking. I get about 3 days of battery with every fitness feature except the heart rate monitor turned off.
Now let's talk about the OS, IT'S AWFUL.  I don't know what Samsung was thinking, Tizen OS is the worst, glitchiest,  and most sluggish operating system i have ever seen. Especially the speak to text feature, 9/10 times it hears the wrong word, or if you speak too fast, it won't even type what you said.  I'm glad the new series 3, 4 and 5 are using google wear OS i hear instead of tizen. That's a step in the right direction, problem is, they made the batteries smaller in those watches instead of larger. So, you're sacrificing battery life to get a proper working operating system on the new watches. I paid 199 for this watch, which i don't think is worth it with how clunky the OS is. If you can get one for under 100 since this version is 4 gens old now, go for it,  the battery is a lot better on this version than the newer watches.

I've been wanting a smart watch for a while now and finally decided to pull the trigger.  My biggest criterion were that it had to be reasonably sized, reasonably priced, have GPS, and be able to have offline maps.  I really liked the look of the Gear S3 Frontier and the Galaxy watches (let's be real - the new 42mm Galaxy watch in black is basically the Frontier's little brother), and I LOVE the rotating bezel.

I tried out both the S3 Frontier and the Galaxy watch and came to the following conclusions.
1) Look - the style of both watches are very similar (which you can see from the product photos).
2) Size - the 46mm Frontier watch is obviously larger than the 42mm Galaxy.  The watch band on the Frontier is thicker and has a slightly wider style that made it look larger than it actually is.  I ended up buying a smaller band similar to the style on the Galaxy to remedy this.  For me, the 42mm Galaxy wins on size.  The screen was only slightly smaller, but the watch as a whole was much smaller (as you can see from my comparison pictures).  The thickness of the two watches is about the same.
3) Rotating Bezel - I found the bezel on the Frontier was easier for me to use.  It's slightly taller than the one on the Galaxy, and the notches on the side are bigger.  The Galaxy bezel fit into the face of the watch a bit more smoothly, so you have to rotate it from the top of the watch, whereas on the Frontier you can rotate it from the side or top.
4) Navigation - navigation through the different widgets and apps was very intuitive on both watches.  You can use the bezel or touchscreen to move through items, and the two buttons on the side to select and navigate.
5) Maps - ultimately this was the item that tipped the scale in favor of the Frontier for me.  There's an app you can download called HERE WeGo which provides directions from your location to your destination.  Very similar to how Google Maps works.  However, it also supports an offline functionality where you can download maps of an area (state / province / etc.) so you have them available without being connected to your phone.  The downside to this is that it doesn't have a satellite or topographic view, but I tested it out locally and the trails I took were all on there.  So if I go hiking somewhere and get lost, I have a general idea of where I am - I can see it on the map.  When I tested HERE WeGo on the new Galaxy watch it doesn't function unless you're connected to the phone, because you can't download offline maps to the Galaxy.  I checked with their support team and they said they will consider it for the future (but that doesn't help me now).

Ultimately I ended up keeping the S3 Frontier and returning the Galaxy.  The Galaxy won on size and waterproof rating, but I just couldn't justify spending almost double on the Galaxy when it wouldn't meet one of my biggest criterion (the offline maps).  It's no Suunto or Garmin or Casio, but for the price point it meets my needs as a GPS watch.

I'll very briefly state that I once owned a fitbit with a wristband that could not be removed and that it caused rashes on my wrist. I wore the Galaxy watch with the default band and it caused a similar effect. When it comes to negatives with the physical device, this is my only complaint. Luckily there are a myriad of choices for wristbands to aleviate this issue. Go wild!

Now onto the stuff I liked.

On my second day with the watch, (being the clumsy idiot I am) I walked in the house with my arms loose as normal as I have not worn a watch for many years, and I slammed my wrist into a door. Obviously this was cause for concern when I saw the scuffs all over the rotating part of the watch. To my surprise, it was the door that had suffered and not the watch! The paint cleaned right off and there was zero damage to the watch. Big points for being tough right off the bat.

The rotating bezel is just plain fun to use to navigate to the different functions, even if you can just flick the screen to achieve the same result. Mine did show some slight lag here and there but it is not to the point where it just isn't working. After using it for a while you can just automatically turn it to what you want without even looking, like shifting gears in a car.

As for the app that pairs with the watch, the usual samsung crap is included like samsung pay, but you at least have the option to keep it off the watch for the most part. As for the rest of the stuff on there, you'll get access to calls, texts, and even e-mails if you're using that specific email service (didn't see gmail but don't quote me on that) which as a first time and admittedly late adopter to the smartwatch era I found incredible. The speaker on the watch is loud and makes calls simple and easy to hear. I didn't even know the watch had a speaker when I bought it so that was a fun surprise.

Through the wearable app you have the ability to reorganize all the apps on the watch as well as remove or add as you desire, and it's fairly simple to use so anyone willing to just read what's on the screen will be able to customize the layout to suit their needs best.

For many I assume that the health features are the reason for the purchase, as that was my main draw for it. There's dozens upon dozens of exercises the watch can help keep track of, including even some weight lifting. It has a step counter, - of course - a heartrate monitor, stress tracker(?), sleep tracker, and has pretty much everything that the phone version of samsung health features in a compact package. If you do not have the watch connected to your phone, when you reconnect it'll synchronize all the data together so even if you had one device away from you charging, the other will count your steps for example and then bring that data to one spot when you reconnect. The sleep tracker caught me off guard with how spot on it seems to be with your sleep times. I kept watch on that for about a week and I think it'd be a valuable tool for those trying to maintain a consistent sleep schedule.

Some people I saw complained that the heart rate monitor was draining their battery quickly, but you can set it to check only when you initiate that so keep it in mind. I'll typically get a full 4 days with it charged to max, but this is just everyday use without much heartrate monitor use or health tracking. It's about 3 days and a half when I do use it to track exercise, so it's still a pretty awesome battery life considering how much smaller it is compared to the larger watch model. There are many options for you to mess around with in order to optimize battery life, so just don't let the "heartrate monitor" reviewers scare you off about how long it lasts.

There is much more that can be said about the device, but for those of us not too interested in having the latest model and just needing it for a little extra ease in life, I can fully recommend this watch. It certainly doesn't hurt that it's a nice looking piece, and with the seemingly endless options for wristbands and watch faces, no two watches ever have to look exactly the same.

I bought the smaller, 42mm, version of this watch and received it yesterday (4 days after ordering).

FIRST IMPRESSION: The watch looks great and is actually the exact same size as the analog watch that I've worn for years, albeit a tad thicker. I was worried that the 46mm version would be too big on my wrist, and, based on how this one looks on my wrist, I was right. To give you an idea of how big my wrist is, this watch has two holes left on the band once worn at a comfortable tightness. (The watch also comes with another band that has more holes for a larger wrist). The rubber band that comes with the watch is minimalist and looks fine, but I wanted something a little more classy, so I ordered a brown leather band to spruce up the looks (it should be delivered next week). Also, you can see from my picture on the underside of the watch that it is super easy to switch bands using the little toggle switches. I like that this watch doesn't look like a smartwatch at first glance. It really does look like a regular analog watch.

EASE OF USE:  I was able to jump right in and start using this watch with no issues. It took me about 45 minutes to set everything up, including downloading the apps for my phone, signing in to my accounts, and tweaking all of the settings to my liking. The rotating bezel makes it super easy to navigate around the menus, and the touchscreen is very responsive to swipes and taps. The screen looks great and is very clear and bright. I have my brightness set on 7, and it is perfect for being outside in the daylight or indoors. This 42mm version might be a tad too small of a screen for some, but it is just right for me. The battery took about an hour to fully charge, and it was on 25% when I received it, so I would guess 1 hour and 20 minutes to full charge from zero.

DAY 1 BATTERY and USAGE IMPRESSIONS: I put the watch on at about 7 pm on day 1 and was messing with it most of the night, switching watch faces and exploring the options and tweaking settings. I then set it to Goodnight Mode (to turn off all notifications except alarm), and set it to track my sleep. The alarm vibrates and makes a sound. I'm not sure if the sound can be turned off...if so, I haven't figured out how. I'm a fairly heavy sleeper, and it was enough to wake me up. Also, the snooze option worked and was easy to do half-asleep. As I'm writing this, the watch has been on my wrist for about 19hrs, and it is at 72%. At this rate, I'll be able to get about 3 days of use, which is what the literature claims.

TIZEN & APPS: I was worried that I wouldn't like the fact that the Tizen OS doesn't allow you to download 3rd party apps, and this IS a huge shortcoming for the watch. However, I have my phone on me all day, so there's really nothing I would want my watch to do that I wouldn't be fine with reaching into my pocket and pulling out my phone for. Anything else added to the watch (as far as apps) would be gimmicky and just extra. The main thing for me is that it DOES work with most third-party apps as far as notifications. My main concern was that I wouldn't be able to get text notifications because I use Textra for texting on my phone. But I was able to set the watch to get notifications from Textra, and when tested I was able to respond to the text using my watch. The Samsung app store is a joke, and 99% of the apps on there don't work at all. That was a huge disappointment.

SPOTIFY NEGATIVE: I was excited to get to use Spotify on the watch with Bluetooth headphones. BUT, the Spotify streaming service only works on the watch if you have a Premium account, which I do not. So, there's that.

PROS:
-Looks great, classy (with a better band), and looks just like an analog watch.
-Easy to use: The bezel, buttons, and menus all work together flawlessly.
-Easy-to-replace bands. Plus, you can find a ton of bands online for fairly cheap.
-Answering calls (and talking) is easy and clear and eliminates the need to pull your phone out (given that you're in an area where you can just talk aloud on speaker.)
-Samsung Health works great at tracking steps, calories, etc, and the app also offers a lot of options for exercise programs and workout ideas, which is great for someone like me who is moderately active and needs a little push and assistance to get moving.

CONS:
-Tizen has limits as far as 3rd party app support, and the Samsung store is laughable, but you can still get notifications from most 3rd party apps.
-While there are lots of options for watch faces, there's only a small amount of free ones that are decent. Most of them will cost you $2-$4.
-Pricepoint is a little high. I was able to use my Health Savings Account card to purchase this watch due to having Type 1 Diabetes and getting my doctor to sign a paper saying the fitness aspect would help regulate my blood sugar, but if I wasn't able to do that I probably wouldn't have bought this watch because of the price.

I brought the smaller 42mm Galaxy watch in midnight black. My wrist is small and kind of narrow, the 42mm Galaxy watch fits perfectly.  I brought a black steel band for the watch but the band that came with the watch is so soft and light that I decided to use the watch with the standard black silicone band. The Galaxy watch is very light, I don't feel that I am wearing it. This watch can be use by itself or link by bluetooth to a android or an iOS smartphone.  I don't have a smartphone and the Galaxy watch app cannot be installed on a tablet, only a smartphone.  I try to install the Galaxy watch app on my Samsung Galaxy Tab S4 tablet, it would not install, a message said that the tablet is not an appropriate device. I install the software on the Galaxy watch standalone and connect it to my home network.  The Galaxy watch is working perfectly as a standalone smartwatch.  I will purchase a smartphone in the future but this smartwatch can be use without a smartphone but not using all of it's features. The 42mm Galaxy watch has approximately 2 - 3 days of charge before charging it again. The larger 46mm Galaxy watch has approximately 4 - 5 days of charge before having to place the watch on the charger. It will take approximately 2 hours to completely charge the Galaxy watch from 0 to 100%. I charge the Galaxy watch every morning while I am washing myself and getting dress. This is a feature rich and a very powerful smartwatch.  I had use a Garmin VIVOactive HR and a Fitbit Ionic smartwatch before purchasing the Samsung Galaxy watch. I notice that the price of the Galaxy watch is going down. Before buying a smartwatch,  cut out a 46mm circle out of cardboard and a 42mm circle,  place both on your wrist to see which size fits your wrist better.  The Samsung Galaxy Watch is one of the better smartwatch being sold. Goggle which smartwatch is the best or the better smartwatch being sold today. Samsung Galaxy Watch will be high on the list. I personal highly recommend the Samsung Galaxy Watch either the larger 46mm or the smaller 42mm size.

This is my first smartwatch, and I bought it more to test it out.  I really wasn't sure I was going to keep it, but after using it for about a month, I can say this will stay on my wrist daily.  The watch looks great.  I am glad I got the 42mm as the black on black is really sleek.  It makes my fiends iWatch look like a toy.  The screen is very clear and easy to see even outside.  I leave it set to brightness level of "6" and it adjusts for me when needed.  The watch faces are very cool, and there are literally thousands you can get, and many are free.  You can make this look like a fancy watch, a Casio, a gadget, tactical, and everything in between.  Really a fantastic looking watch.

For battery life, I average 3 days.  My first two charges didn't last as long, and I was a little worried.  But now I get three days with room to spare.  I do not sleep with it.  I put in airplane mode at night.  It is on my wrist and in use for 12-18 hours a day.  I have Wifi off, and location off because my Note 9 handles all that through Bluetooth.  I only have it monitor my heartrate when I am doing an exercise.  I take calls on it regularly, check email and texts, and use it for fitness.  I would say I am a moderate user.

I love the built in altimeter and barometer, and found them to be reasonably accurate.  I also found the step tracking to be fairly accurate as well, though it does miss some steps here and there.  Sometimes it is simply delayed.  Tizen OS is smooth and easy to use, but there are not a lot of apps yet in the Samsung universe.  There are way behind Google and Apple in this respect.  I hope they keep updating their apps to better more useful ones, because right now, they are not that great.

Overall I love this watch.  I am very happy I decided to try this out.  It really does make me think how I lived without one for so long.

I have had this watch for I think 2 years now, and this watch has been amazing, the bezel works very seamlessly, the UI is very smooth and works very well. The system with the phone is very nice I can use it to track fitness, my music, phone calls. Plus it even has a speaker in it so you can answer calls and listen to music through the watch speaker if you need. The apps you can get are an amazing never ending feature. It runs off of the galaxy store but your not limited at all. So many useful apps to choose from and a list that keeps expanding makes it never get old. I highly reccomend this watch, just aware that Bezel is not super FL against the watch so if you spill something on it you might get something inside of it that can make it feel sticky or just stop moving. But it's okay it's waterproof so washing it in the sink whilst moving the bezel cleans it right up like it's brand new.

My only gripe is it's battery at first I could get almost 2 days out of the watch now I have to charge it every night. But other than that it works very well and highly reccomned it.

I love my Samsung Galaxy Watch! When I was looking for smart watches, I was tempted to buy the Samsung Galaxy Watch Active which was just launched back then. However, that one didn't had all the features that makes this one a great smartwatch. I love being able to pick up a call and talk through the watch, people hear me perfectly and I hear them very well. In addition, when I'm home I connect to WiFi rather than bluetooth, it gives me a greater range and watch does not disconnect when I leave the phone in another room.

Pros:
-Amazing battery time, can last over a week depending on use. (For example, only connecting BT when not home).
-Tracks my stress levels several times a day, it is accurate. Has a relaxation feature with breathing exercises. LOVE IT.
-Tracks my BPM, accurate but you need to stay still.
-Samsung Health is a good app. I track my bike rides and it syncs with the phone app without any issues. I have yet to use Strava.
-Alarms! But also, alarms set on the phone only will also go off on the watch. So no need to have alarms set on watch and phone. BT or WiFi needs to be connected for this.
-SmartThings: can control my Samsung Smart TV from my watch (WiFi connected)
-Can control Spotify
-Find my phone and find my watch functions.

Basic functions:
-Step counter, not incredible accurate but then again I haven't tried any other device for this.
-Calories burned during exercise.
-Actual watch, wide range of faces to choose from. Analog, digital, combined, there is a watch face for every taste.

Things I have not tried:
-Sleep tracking. I mean, the watch is comfortable and all, but I cannot sleep with any accessory on.

Some cons, not a big deal for me:
-GPS seems to be a little unrealiable.
-Sometimes when measuring BPM or stress (which is measure based on BPM) the watch would give an error and ask you to clean the sensor.
-That same sensor, will go off when you are not wearing the watch, presumably for the automatic BPM and stress measures, but it should have a way to tell you are not wearing it and not try again and again.

But the cons are not a deal breaker for me. Maybe I'm doing something wrong or not using it as I should. Anyway, completely recommend this smartwatch even after there is a newer version out there. I don't think the newer ones have this amazing battery life and versatility this one has.

That is all, hope this helps. Oh, remember to pair with a Samsung phone to enjoy ALL the features. ??

A couple of quick notes before I get into the review:

-I'm reviewing the 42mm version, which I've had for about 3 weeks now.
-Apple vs. Samsung comparisons are overblown; both are good watches, but obviously you should match your watch to your phone
-I don't think there's a better smartwatch available at the moment, but I'm only giving this watch 4 stars because I don't think smartwatch technology has fully matured at this stage; I'd say there are no 5 star smartwatches at the moment

Bottom line: The Galaxy Watch does almost everything I was hoping for, and does it pretty well
-My settings: AoD on with a simple face, brightness 3, location off, HR every 10 min, voice activation off; I use the watch whenever I'm away from home – appx 11hrs/day
-With those settings and that usage pattern, I get through 2 days on a charge with a bit to spare
-Reading and responding to notifications is smooth
-Overall, I'd say the exercise tracking is pretty good, not great
-Step counting seems accurate for walking at a reasonable pace, but inaccurate for slow walking or a mix of walking/standing (such as when moving through a museum)
-I mainly use S Health for HR tracking, which works well for steady state cardio but less well for weight training. I'm not sure if it’s thrown off by rapid fluctuations in my HR, moving around a bit on wrist during exercise, or what, but it often loses track of my HR, lags behind spikes and dips, and doesn’t seem to reach true peaks
-For weight lifting, S health isn’t that useful; it can’t count reps on that many exercises and doesn't allow for custom workout design
-I use an app (gymrun) that allows custom workout design; it doesn’t track HR or count reps, but you can manually enter reps and use S health (on ‘other workout’) to track HR
-I was hoping that the Galaxy Watch would allow me to leave my phone in my locker at the gym, and that I'd be able to use the watch to (1) play music, (2) track my workout, and (3) connect to wifi so I can send/receive texts/emails
-The good news is that the watch is capable of doing all of that with no lag – even when running music + wifi + S health continuous HR monitoring + gymrun
-The bad news is that the watch can’t connect to captive portal wifi (networks that require you to visit a website and accept terms), and that  the watch burns through appx 30% battery in an hour if you do all of that
-The floors-climbed counter is mixed; it's sometimes quite accurate but sometimes misses floors

Style, comfort, and build
-I'm a male of above average height, and the 42mm watch face is right size for me; there are online watch face size calculators based on wrist size – you’d have to have quite large wrists for a larger watch to look ‘appropriate’
-Of course style is subjective and some prefer a larger face, but for me, 42mm is as large as I was willing to go, and the availability of a 42mm version was a huge selling point
-The watch looks good overall; it's not the world’s best looking watch but certainly something that’s well worth wearing anywhere from the gym to the office to a night out
-The watch is thicker than I anticipated; from the side, it looks quite chunky
-It's very comfortable; I don't notice it during the day, even when typing; it doesn’t get in the way while lifting weights
-Build quality seems good so far – no dents or scratches, but it hasn’t seen hard knocks

Hardware
-This is where the Galaxy Watch really shines, in 2 areas in particular: the SoC (chip that powers the watch) and the rotating bezel
-I don’t think I’ll ever use a watch without a rotating bezel; it's the best way to interact with a smartwatch by far – it allows you to navigate without blocking/smudging the screen or maneuvering both hands to spin a tiny wheel on a side button
-The SoC blows away everyone but apple; wear os watches are 2+ generations behind
-As a result, battery life is excellent (by current smartwatch standards) and apps run smoothly

Software
-This is most people’s biggest complaint – not so much the OS but the limited app availability
-Tizen OS is actually quite intuitive, fluid, and customizable
-Lack of apps does not bother me – aside from the use cases I described up top, I’d rather use my phone for any other apps anyway
-But google integration is not perfect and many apps are not available; if this is something you care about, do some research about what is/is not available on the watch

I am always leary buying something used but, I took a leap of faith and ordered a 42mm watch. It was in used/like new condition. It arrived a few days after ording and as advertised it came in a white aftermarket box and contained an OEM charging block, cable and charger. Overall the watch was in good condition. There were some light surface marks on it but, I was looking for blemishes. The watch face did not have any scratches. The band which was an OEM black plastic band was a little dirty but, cleaned up by using a clorox wipe on it. It was dead so it tood a little for it to charge up. Installed the app and got everying up and running with little effort. Using it my first day I found that I still needed to tweek some of the settings. I had plenty of battery left at the end of the day. I charged it overnight and decided I wanted to see how much battery life I would have. I ended up with one full day/night and the battery took me through to a 2nd day and at 930 pm I was down to about 3% battery. I have no issue charging daily but, wanted to see if I ended up working late how much time would I have before it goes dead. My opinion is that I was satisfied with just about 2 days of use. There are an abundance of watch faces to meet everyone's needs and taste. I really wanted a more smart watch to monitor my O2 sats, heart rate, etc and this does a great job in doing that. I also set reminders if I am sedentary too long, it will prompt me to get moving. So, to those who are squeamish on buying used items take the plunge and buy it. Use the money you would have spent on a new watch on a band, screen protector, etc. I realize there are more current watches that do more but, the features on this watch checked off all of my boxes. As for the features, I find the heart rate and O2 measuring are very accurate as well as the step tracking. Very happy with this purchase!

I had a Frontier S3 that unfortunately died after 2.5 years. I loved that watch but I decided if I was going to buy a new smart watch I wanted to research all options. I didn't want an apple watch because I had their first generation watch (which was fine), I use a Samsung phone, and it seems like everyone has an apple watch. When I had my frontier I always got complements because it looks different and like a real watch. I looked at fitbit, garmin, and others and decided that I really did like the features and look of the Samsung watch best. Of course then I had to decide between the new Active and 2 different sizes of the Galaxy. I chose the Galaxy because it had the bezel and also the integrated speaker which is nice. If I didn't care about those 2 things I probably would have selected the Active. Then I debated about the size and whether to stick with the slightly large 46mm form factor the frontier had or the smaller 42mm. I went to a Verizon store to see the difference in person and landed on the smaller 42mm size. I'm really happy with it. The watch looks great, has fantastic battery life, and works really well. The SHealth app leaves a little to be desired but I think I'll look around at 3rd party alternatives. One tip - the batteries in these devices have about a 2 year lifespan. Do yourself a favor and get an extended warranty. I searched Amazon and found the ASURION 3 year personal care extended protection plan. It isn't that expensive and basically means you're covered for 4 years in total. Trust me, it's worth it. There are several variations of the protection plans so make sure to get the personal care one I've mentioned. Good luck!
Good, useful product.

reviews.review_body: I just received my hybrid watch. It paired with my Galaxy S7 but the notification features aren't working at all. The other features work like the music and camera but I  bought it for the notification features. Very disappointed!

It is a cool and fashionable watch, YET the fossil app does not play well with android software. It took me four months to figure out that their app was causing the android software to become unstable on my phone and tablet after reloading the software several times and trial and error with all my apps.

I Love this watch.  Being a professional, i needed something that looked nice. Did not want one I had to charge all the time, and really was only looking for message and call notifications so I didn't have to carry my phone around always. This serves the purpose, plus. The vibrations are not real strong, but I found if I wear it looser on my wrist like a bracelet, I feel it better as it rests near my hand. After reading other reviews about the band getting dirty, I initially sprayed the band with a leather protector  that's worked beautifully.  Would definitely recommend.

I got this watch for Christmas, having been in the market for a Fossil Q hybrid for a while, and I love it. It's stylish and I can still track my steps when away from my phone. Keep in mind it doesn't monitor heart rate if that is something you are in the market for. It also has the potential to monitor sleep, but I can just see myself shattering the watch face while tossing and turning, so I don't take advantage of that one.

The band on this model is a very light leather so this model will get dirtier quicker than the others. My only warning is that as this is a normal watch battery, having all the fancy text notifications and whatnot will run the battery down quicker. This is a potential inconvenience, but the app does a good job at telling where the battery of the watch is. I got very nervous after going through 5% of the battery within a couple of days, but I turned off text notifications and I have been at 95% for almost a month since.
Love this watch!
Love it!!!!!
I am super bummed as it broke already
crystal cracked after 2 months, no warranty on crystal through Fossil, crap company, crap product!!!
Awesome watch my wife loved it!!
We have 4 total of the Q's. They're phenomenal.

reviews.review_body: I bought this watch on Amazon.  Big mistake.  Buy quality timepieces only from dealers you know and trust. I had to go through the seven circles of Hades to return it, but finally got it returned and got my money back.  Never again will I buy a watch on Amazon.  I feel sorry for people who do not know watches very well and get ripped off buying worthless replicas.

reviews.review_body: Really a great one. I purchased it from B&M's authorized retail shop and it is a second year as I own it. Design, quality and look are impeccable. Must have one!

I've been researching a luxury watch for some time, and this is the one I finally settled on.  I could not be more pleased.  It has an elegant, classical appeal - which some may find old fashioned - but it sits very nicely on my wrist.  The black band, silver case, white face and uncluttered display are very pleasing to the eye.  I found the BM clasp a bit fiddly at first, but now I have adapted and enjoy the flat buckle fit.  Although I didn't realise it at the time of purchase, it has a 24 hour subdial, with a secondary time zone hand - an unexpected bonus.  Very happy indeed.

I purchased this watch from an authorized Baume & Mercier dealer.  I did so because they added one year to the warranty and do all of the repairs and maintenance (if needed) on site.  In addition, they did give me a nice reduction in price, which I have found is not unusual for upscale watches.  Okay, it isn't as good a price as I could get on line, but this is not a gray market watch and comes with a full U.S. warranty.  Often, the discounted watches are gray market and do not come with an American warranty.  I looked at other watches, including one by Tag Heuer and also Mont Blanc.  But when I saw them in person, I found that they looked like very expensive sports watches.  To be sure, they were very fine looking.  But for me I find that the Baume & Mercier looks more elegant.  This is a watch that I will not wear daily (I am very active in the high Rockies ... wearing a Baume & Mercier while backcountry skiing at 12,000 ft altitude is sort of over the top).  I have recently purchased a watch winder so that the watch will not loose time while it sits in its case.  This has been a great purchase, looks wonderful, and is a great anniversary gift for me!

reviews.review_body: I love this watch, it simple yet beautiful.  You can't appreciate it fully until you put it on your wrist. I also love the fact it's a dive watch that doesn't look like it's trying to copy a Rolex Submariner.

This is a really spectacular watch.  I wore a Submariner no date for years, and it was a great watch, but I didn't like the newly updated version with the ceramic dial (a nice upgrade) and the bulging body (blingy and unbecoming for a Rolex). This watch combines the best attributes of both Submariners (a classic design with a nearly indestructible ceramic bezel), with Omega's terrific co-axial caliber 8400 movement, which keeps time as well or better than any watch I've owned. The photos do not capture how well the polished links and bezel elements pick up the light and contrast with the matte black bezel with vintage style lume (though do be prepared to wipe it regularly, the mirror like finish does pick up finger prints quickly).  And if you don't want to deal with fingerprints, it also looks great and understated on a NATO, as seen in James Bond Spectre.  It's just an overall stunning watch in person that immediately displaced the rest of my collection as my daily wearer, and yes, it will go SCUBA diving with me soon enough.

I can say I would take this without hesitation over the new SubC and it has (at least for now) relegated my older Sub to the closet. The Jaeger Tribute to Deepsea and Blancpain Fifty Fathoms are very similar looking; they obviously have a rarity factor that the Omega doesn't, but I'm not sure they're better watches, espeiclaly when you look at things like the 8400s unique co-axial technology and 15,000 gauss anti-magnetic protection. Throw in a not insignificant price difference and it was an easy call for me.

Highly recommended.

reviews.review_body: The Raymond Weil Tradition Watch offers the flexibility for use in both casual dress or business suit applications. The watch is of a timeless design and is of very high quality and build. The Swiss ETA movement is the finest such Quartz movement available today and the case is equal in quality to most all of the finest Swiss manufacturers. The face of the watch is a perfect size and the Genuine Crocodile Leather Strap is elegant and a keeper. Considering the watch is being sold today at 55% off list price; this represents one of the best values out there. A similiar Baume Mercier or Oris Watch would run about $1,300 to $3,500. The overall look and quality is better than similiar Tissot Classics especially the movement itself. This Raymond Weil has an inspired look of a Patek Phillippe yet retains the elegant casual look of a Baume Mercier Watch. Amazing looks, great value and a great addition to any collection!!!

I've owned 2 Raymond Weil watches prior to purchasing this one and I loved both of them.  This watch is the complete opposite of the first 2 I owned. It is a nice looking watch alright, if you like gold tone dress watches with silver tone dial, and I wear it occasionally. The size is just right, not tiny, but far from ostentatious. But the quality does seem somewhat suspect. After only a few months, some cogs are skipped when winding manually, not a good sign even for this lower end brand. Other than that it still works fine though, and I have it on a winder, so we'll see.

Initially loved this watch, it appeals to the aesthetic senses and served its function well. However I started running into problems about two months in when it stopped ticking while still on my wrist, suggesting that the self winding movement was going through some problems. However this eventually went away and I thought it some sort of clockwork hiccup. About 4 days before the return deadline it completely stopped functioning; no amount of winding, or moral encouragements could get it to tick again. I didn't spend close to a grand for a lackadaisical watch, although I suppose that could add some character. Whether this is Amazon's handling/QA fault or Raymond Weil's is the question. Either way, my refund was not processed because while I dropped it off at UPS 2 days prior to the cut off, it didn't arrive until a couple of days later so buyers beware.

Omega Men s 2909 50 38 Seamaster Planet Ocean Automatic Chronometer Orange Leather Watch

reviews.review_body:
I am rather opinionated when it comes to luxury watches.  This comes from spending 2 years in watchmaking school, studying directly under the guidance of a certified master swiss watchmaker who came here from Europe.  Watches, especially mid to high grade swiss watches, are a passion of mine.  I am not loyal to a brand or a style or anything else.  I judge them for what they are, in terms of quality, function, construction, and style.  A watchmakers point of view.

This said I will tell you that this particular watch is what I consider to be a "best kept secret" sort of watch.  This is an AUTOMATIC watch (read: Mechanical - NOT Quartz), and of CHRONOMETER grade function.  Chronometer as used here is a measure of accurate timekeeping, not quality - a point often misunderstood - and is used mostly from a marketing point of view by companies such as Rolex.  HOWEVER.  This movement in THIS watch is actually EXCELLENT in terms of quality, time keeping ability, and construction - easily comparable to other Swiss made movements from other famous manufacturers costing several times as much.  This watch, properly serviced, will provide a lifetime of use - and probably more.  Absolutely the sort of watch you pass down to the next generation.

All in all - and EXCELLENT choice - especially for those seeking their first QUALITY Swiss watch purchase.

Definitely recommended!

reviews.review_body: I love this watch. It has so many funtions, most in which I haven't been able to master using yet but I am working on it. To me this watch resembles a G-Shock, sort of, but far less expensive. It has an alarm fucntion as well as a timer, it tells you what day of the week it is. It can be set to military time and it chimes every hour on the hour. Some of the functions are hard to maneuvre around but if you play with it for a little while you will get the hang of it. The instructions that come with try their best to lead you through all the functions but some of it is trial and error, I think.

PAUL HEWITT Unisex Analogue Quartz Watch with Leather Strap PH SA G Sm B 12M Blue Green Strap

reviews.review_body: Slim, attractive, just right. They call it a "lady's watch" but I have a smallish wrist and large watches look stupid on me. See the photo for proof that a 36mm watch looks fine on a man. (It's reasonably thin for a dress watch too).

product_title: Omega Men s 2517 30 00 Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz Watch
Omega Men s 2517 30 00 Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz Watch
Omega Men s 2517 30 00 Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz Watch
Omega Men s 2517 30 00 Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz Watch
Omega Men s 2517 30 00 Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz Watch

reviews.review_body: It took them forever to deliver the item. Even though it had a specific delivery date, they did NOT meet it.

First, don't listen to reviews that have nothing to do with the watch which serve no purpose and don't belong in a review section, but a seller section. Reviews should be about the watch, seller reviews should be about the seller. Buying from a unauthorized dealer in Israel and have omega pay for it has nothing to do with the watch itself. Nor does a delivery not happening have anything to do with the watch.

Now for a real review.

The attention to detail in this watch is on par with anything from a Automatic version of this watch. Only difference is the movement. Other than that they are the same. Being a person who owns a couple Rolex autos, omega autos, the fit and finish of this Aqua Terra and rivals
Any of them. What you are getting here is a watch with the build quality Omega is known for.

The new Quartz versions of this watch are not made as well as this one here. They have painted on indices, not applied, painted logo not applied. Here is a fast fact. They are not making anymore of this version of the Aqua Terra with the same build quality as the autos. The new ones compared to the Autos are made to look cheaper. These are not.

Omega is one of the top brand of watches in the world, period. Easily on par with Rolex, and in some cases surpasses them. Google a Rolex Sub vs a Sea-master and look at the comparisons. This watch is going to go up in value, since they don't make them anymore.

The watch face is 39.2 mm, compared to the newer models of 38.5mm. The movement in this is the Omega is the 1538 a rhodium plated 6 jewel movement. It has a independent hour hand setting for traveling which is convenient. I own a quartz Bond Sea-master and a 2016 Planet ocean auto. My seamaster with a 1538 quartz movement is accurate to 00.8 seconds a month! This is straight from Omega after a overhaul. My planet ocean isn't close to that and it has a Co-Axial 8500 movement which is considered by many as one of the most accurate on the planet, even surpasses the 3135 from a Rolex sub! Not that I am expecting a Auto to be as accurate as a quartz, since buying a Auto with the accuracy of a quartz isn't why a you buy a Auto. You buy a Auto for the craftsmanship and art of the movement. A quartz is bought for accuracy and convenience.

The band of the watch is superb, its sliding mechanism makes putting on and taking off the watch a breeze, the case is finely polished and the dial has the attention to detail which is expected of a Omega watch. The band is very comfortable and does not pinch the arm or gets uncomfortable after extended wear. My only gripe is that the clasp sliding mechanism could be a little shorter and it tends to make the weight of the watch a little uneven depending on where you have links removed. But hardly noticeable. Not a deal breaker by any means.

Omega's customer service is second to none. When you go to a Omega Boutique they have a sitting area with Cappuccino, Espresso, and your snack of choice, cookie, shortbread etc. You get pampered and are shown respect. Any thing I asked them to do they did happily! Never in the 15 years of owning a Omega have I had a bad experience with them. Now am i saying they don't mess up. No. They do. Everyone does, but they make it right in the long run. It's how they tackle and fix problems, not the problems themselves. That is a true mark excellence in my opinion. I get treated better by Omega than by Rolex.

Now is this a replacement for a Auto, no. It's not meant to be. But if you want a well made watch this is more accurate than any auto, has the build quality of Omega is known for and a customer experience to back it up. This Aqua Terra is a good choice.

Overall, the Omega Sea Master Aqua Terra is a beautiful watch that reflects a simple but elegant design and sturdy construction.  While this watch may not be as desirable as the automatic movement version, it is nevertheless a beautiful watch that works well and is a joy to own.  Plus think of it this way -- you don't have to worry about winding the watch every couple of days.  The trade-off is up to you.

Bought Seamaster Aqua Terra Quartz in official dealer shop in Israel and actually was given already defected watch (sell person knew it well)- date setting function did not work.  Watch was exchanged and after 3 weeks of usage same issue re-occured already on new  watch.
 I took this upto Omega and Local  official dealer and explained, that I expected something more durable and honest starting from buying and  throughout  usage of "luxury" product
Solution from Omega? Take same watch 3rd time! For me twice was enough and I asked for some better solution and compensation for  my disappointment and dealer agreed to give me watch of ... TISSOT as a compensation. I was shocked and amused.
Attempt to explain difference between Omega and Tissot buyers profile were fruitless. Official dealer did nto agree to upgrade my watch to another Omega one for unhonesty of their shop during purchase and product  bad quality.
At the end, after  3 months,  my purchase was refunded, watch returned  and I was granted to pick up complimentary SWATCH  watch for all the inconvenience  :-)
Offical Omega? No response at all.
So for me and my family members Omega is the sign of bad quality, ugly customer support and not understanding their customer profile. My advice to collegues and friends - never buy Omega, especially in Israeli "Impress" shops and "Roltime Ltd" dealer.

product_title: Omega Men s 23110392103001 Analog Display Automatic Self Wind Silver Watch
Omega Men s 23110392103001 Analog Display Automatic Self Wind Silver Watch
Omega Men s 23110392103001 Analog Display Automatic Self Wind Silver Watch

reviews.review_body: Love this watch! Came in great condition. Took it to an Omega store to verify its authenticity as i tend to be very cautious buying watches online even if it was fulfilled by amazon. Everything looks good on this one.

Great watch and reasonable size at 39mm. Co-axial movement keeps incredible time. Very comfortable to wear. The build quality is equal or better than Rolex at a much lower price point, although resale/trade is poor relative to Rolex. Display back is an added bonus.

product_title: Breitling Men s E1338310 M534 109W Avenger Chronograph Grey Fabric Watch
Breitling Men s E1338310 M534 109W Avenger Chronograph Grey Fabric Watch

reviews.review_body: I've been looking at Breitling for years but have been hesitant due to the weight that these watches can pack. I prefer larger watches because I have large hands, but I'm not crazy about having a heavy item strapped to my wrist. --->Finally, Breitling has designed a watch perfect to my needs. It's a 45mm watch that wears more like a 44mm. It is titanium, which is substantially lighter than stainless steel, and has a 22mm canvas strap that tapers down to 20mm. It has a rubber inlay which keeps the watch from sliding up and down the wrist, holding it in one position throughout the day. I love it. I'll come back in 6 months to provide an update on the build quality of the strap, and give an honest opinion on my first, post honeymoon, Breitling experience.

We bought it with a 14 yr old FSU Fan in mind. And for that person and that purpose, couldnt be better,

I bought this for our youngest son, and it's exactly what he wanted. Good price
and good quality. Would recommend this to others.
I got this for my son, who is an Auburn fan. He loves it and he likes the stainless steel back, and the easily adjustable band.
For the price, this is a nice watch. My Georgia boy hubby loves his! Casual watch and great for date night. Still going strong several months after purchase and no defects.
This is a nice watch. I wasnt looking for anything fancy as my fiancee wears it to work and such. It is good quality and even nicer in person!

Nice watch face, adjustable Velcro band, but not cheap looking. Great price for a casual everyday watch. Returned two other Purdue watches which were kind of bulky looking before settling on this one. Go Boilers!!
Poor qulaity. The hands fell loose within a year of owning it.
The game time watch was a birthday gift for a friend. He really love the watch and thanks me for he is a big UM fan

The watch arrived with several of the metal pieces that mark the five minutes intervals free and floating under the glass.  While the watch was actually working it is only a matter of time before they get wedged in and stop the hands from moving.
The band isn't the nicest, but it was easy to replace. The picture does not do the face justice, it's so much nicer looking in person. He loved it!
It wasn't very durable. It broke rather quickly.
Loved the price!  Love the watch!  I bought one of these for a gift for Christmas, I wanted more but wanted to see first.  After seeing, I ordered two more.  Great gifts!
It is an excellent timekeeper. I have owned the watch for about two weeks and it has neither gained nor lost a perceptible amount of time in that period.
I bought my dad this watch last year and he wore it so much he literally wore it out.  So I found it in here and bought it again.  He loves it!
I changed out the band as it was too big for me, but once I got a band that I fit, I loved the watch.  The watch is very attractive!
I got this watch for fathers day because he is a big fan of Clemson. He absolutely loves it.
Go State!  Had it for almost a year and it's still going strong and looks great. My husband even got a compliment on it just last night.
Beautiful ...

It was a gift for my Son-In-Law and this is the Second one he has had...Had one for MANY years and asked for another at Christmas so I think he really loves it

it was what i expected
